reviewText:
Making the movie of Eat Pray Love must have been daunting.  How can a journey of self-discovery make an interesting film, even if it is set in three of the most amazing places on the planet?

Somehow it works seamlessly.  Eat Pray Love is a gorgeous film. It's funny and poignant and mesmerizing and moving, and it's restored my faith in movies. The filmmakers took a few liberties with Gilbert's book in the interest of pacing and story and the changes made it better.

Casting Julia Roberts as Elizabeth Gilbert was brilliant. Though we never forget we're watching Julia Roberts, in much the same way Bette Davis and Joan Crawford dominated their roles, she manages to be endearing and believable as she flounders in the wreckage of her life and tries to figure out what's next.  The amazing thing is that the effort behind her progress from depression to joy never shows.  It's demonstrated in subtle ways--roars of laughter at a still-frozen Thanksgiving turkey, pangs of memory and release of pain evoked by a wedding, mischievous glee at giving up her "I'm in silence" badge at the ashram. Julia Roberts' Elizabeth Gilbert is likeable and charming and her internal journey is wonderful to watch.

I liked the book, Eat Pray Love for the travel and the characters, but thought the self-discovery was a 'meh'--yet another spoiled baby-boomer dissatisfied with a life far better than that of 99.9% of the rest of the world who spent 400 pages and a year in the most amazing places on earth crying, "Me me me". I didn't like Elizabeth Gilbert very much and didn't totally buy a lot of the internal story, though I lapped up the tales of her experiences and the people she met on her travels.  Thanks to a really fine screenplay, we see the point to Eat Pray Love in a way that was sometime obscured in the book.  Thanks to a really fine cast, the supporting characters are just that, from Billy Crudup as Gilbert's hurt and bewildered ex-husband, James Franco as the actor who introduces Gilbert to meditation and Viola Davis as the best friend and sounding board.  Gilbert's circle of people in each of the three places she visits are pitch-perfect and never succumb to stereotype.  It should be noted that Richard Jenkins comes close to stealing the movie in India, as he exhorts Gilbert with AA-like fervor, variations of "It works if you work it" and "keep coming back" that mask regret and heartbreak. The scenes with him are some of the best in the movie, though there's not a weak link in the cast.

Even if you hated the book, Eat Pray Love is worth seeing as an example of a truly well-made movie with an exceptional cast--and be prepared to crave pizza margherita for days afterwards.

Isn't it nice to have the time, the resources, and the money to be able to travel the world and rediscover life, love, and spirituality? We should all be as lucky as Elizabeth Gilbert. Her memoir, "Eat, Pray, Love: One Woman's Search for Everything Across Italy, India and Indonesia," has sold millions, been on the "New York Times" Best Seller list for 158 weeks, and touched the lives of thousands. One of them was Oprah Winfrey, who devoted two whole episodes of her show to the book. I admit that I haven't read it, but I have done a little research on it and on Gilbert herself. I have to say, I don't much care for her or her story. Her journey of discovery, paid for by an advance on a novel she plans to write, seemed awfully selfish, for she had no real absences in her life; she was married, had an education, was a successful writer, and lived comfortably in New York. This wasn't enough for her?

The film "Eat Pray Love," which adapts Gilbert's story and has her portrayed by Julia Roberts, tells us that no, it wasn't enough. She divorces her husband (Billy Crudup), who, in an early divorce settlement scene, gave me more reason to side with him than with her. She has an affair with an attractive and all-around nice young actor (James Franco), which she then ends in a brazen display of tears brought on by God knows what. She then decides that it's time to take a year off and travel the world, to reconnect with herself, to once again have a zest for life - in other words, to escape from all the good things she had but never appreciated. She proceeds to spend four months in Italy, where she happily eats as much pasta and pizza as she can, with a few Napoleons on the side. She then spends the next four months in an Indian ashram, where the tries her hand at meditation, apparently under the impression that God can be grasped in one fell swoop. Finally, she goes to Bali, where she's presented with, but not necessarily willing to accept, love.

Along the way, she just happens to meet a number of people. Never mind the fact that they all greatly impact her life, as such people tend to do in stories like this; it's a miracle they can all speak fluent English. One of them, wouldn't you know it, just happens to be from the great state of Texas. In Italy, she befriends a sassy Swede and a charming Italian, a couple who look like they stepped out of a Giorgio Armani ad. In India, she meets the Texan (Richard Jenkins), a loveably gruff old man whose every line sounds like it originated from a fortune cookie. He, of course, has his own tragic back story, although he only shares it at just such a time when it's most convenient for the plot. In Bali, she reunites with the obligatory wise elder (Hadi Subiyanto), the long suffering divorcee (Christine Hakim), and Felipe (Javier Bardem), who enters her life as men tend to do in most forgettable romantic comedies.

There's nothing about this movie that feels authentic, and that's what infuriates me; it has the gall to pass itself off as an autobiography. I don't care how accurate Elizabeth Gilbert claims it is (she said during a "Good Morning America" interview that it played like a "surreal home movie"). I don't believe her. This is the stuff of movies, not real life. Besides, she didn't visually document her journey at all - not a single photo, not a frame of film. All the more reason not to believe her. With so much doubt about the story's authenticity, and with Gilbert's questionable dismissal of the good life she so clearly had before making the journey, the film lacks any sense of spiritual enlightenment or emotional awakening; it comes off as little more than a portrait of a selfish woman on a sightseeing trip.

Julia Roberts is a wonderful actress, and even though I disliked the woman she played, I still thought she gave a good performance. Javier Bardem seems to be channeling the same dashing mystique he employed in the much, much better "Vicky Cristina Barcelona," which is to say he seems to be repeating himself, albeit competently. As for James Franco, let's just say that my mother has coined the perfect phrase for actors that display no range and speak in monotone lulls: "They've just gotten a Novocain enema." I don't know what director Ryan Murphy told him, but whatever he said, it was terrible advice. Franco is usually a very reliable, very convincing actor. Ever seen "Milk"? Hell, ever seen "Spider-Man"?

"Eat Pray Love" is phony, contrived, and unpleasant, made worse by the fact that we're supposed to take it as fact. Don't bother sending me comments that I'm wrong and that everything in the film comes directly from Gilbert's actual experiences. I'm not going to believe you. If the filmmakers had followed the leads of the people behind "Under the Tuscan Sun" and "Letters to Juliet," who had the decency to label their films as works of fiction, then maybe I would have appreciated it more. But then again, no, I wouldn't have; there's still the matter of Elizabeth Gilbert, whose quest for meaning and happiness was really an exercise in trendy New Age mantra-talk and selfishness. The more I think about the journey she made, the less I like her as a person.

Julia Roberts may have liked the book and desperately wanted to be part of the movie but she was way too old. She looked to be in her mid-forties if not fifties and it took me out of the movie. Also, real relationships are hard to come by--true friends, those moments that you feel so connected to other people. Liz seemed to find this in everyone she met. Go get coffee-- the woman who orders for her becomes her best friend. Language teacher--best friend. Everyone she meets is that soul mate of a best friend. I've traveled a bit and I can tell you this doesn't happen. You may meet a person or two, but not EVERYONE. Even the medicine man in Bali tells her she's like his daughter. It  seemed forced and fake. I loved the book because maybe the relationships seemed more natural. This, not so much.

I cried...I felt all sorts of emotions, and I am definitely adding this to my favorite movies list. Julia Roberts does an amazing job as Liz Gilbert. And this movie came at such a great time as I feel myself in an in-between stage as well since it's the end of the summer and school is about to start back. This movie is heart warming, soul inspiring, spirit lifting... I could go on and on. Thank you to the cast and film makers for doing such a great job!

A deeply shallow movie which I feel I have seen many times before under different sauces. Not a single believable character, starting with the heroine who is anguished by... what, exactly? The only time when I thought the narration would stop being nauseatingly fluffy is when the reformed alcoholic Texan started speaking about what immediately turned out to be a non-manslaughter of his young son. But no, a real tragedy was deemed too dark for the audience of this typical self-help film, so instead the makers stuffed it up to the gills with platitudes.

In the end the searching-for-self heroine finds a hot Brazilian who is an excellent father and marriage material! Aww... what a nice accidental find!

I get the urge to watch "Eat Pray Love" periodically. I could look at and listen to Javier Bardem in this movie endlessly - and sometimes do - with that Eddie Vedder song at the end.... SIGH. Many times I've kept hitting Rewind to watch the last 20 minutes over, and over, and over, fantasizing about being in that boat, on that water, being whisked away to an unbelievable life with a guy like THAT... In the past I've had to wait for Netflix to send the disc when I got that urge; but given that I've gone through that frustration several times now, I finally just bought my own copy, and am SO glad I did. No more frustration waiting for my escape fix!

GREAT MOVIE.

What a perfect flick for the entitled ME generation that wants it all and isn't concerned with who they hurt to get it.  Hey, you can't possibly be the reason your life is messed up; if you have a problem, don't face it or solve it -- just walk out of the situation. The main character screws her life up and blows up a fairly decent marriage, and for the rest of the movie, she gives the rest of us advice.

Here's another attempted rationalization of the main character's behavior:

"And we must take care of our families, wherever we find them. Today l saw Tutti playing with a blue tile she'd found in the road near a hotel construction site. She told me: Maybe if we have a house someday, it can have a pretty blue floor like this. When I was in Italy, I learned a word - It's "tutti" with double T, which in ltalian means "everybody." So that's the lesson, isn't it? When you set out in the world to help yourself, sometimes you end up helping Tutti."

So much of the dialog was just as syrupy and sticky as that.  It's like you're at IHOP and you put your sleeve in some syrup and pretty soon it's on everything and you can't get it off.  One reviewer called it 'cheesy' -- that comment is spot on, imo.  "Just hop from one affair to the next, and you'll be a better, happier person, because you'll gain something from each one."  My wife could hardly stand it, and SHE picked the movie out.

Can't believe it got any ratings above 3 stars, but I get it that there are people who enjoy Julia Roberts enough to give anything she's in a good rating.  I like her too, but not enough to forgive dialog like this:

Liz Gilbert: I did love you, Stephen.
Stephen: I know. But I still love you.
Liz Gilbert: So, love me.
Stephen: But I miss you.
Liz Gilbert: So, miss me. Send me love and light every time you think of me... Then drop it. It won't last forever. Nothing does.

Aaughhh!!  Ladies, there are better chick flicks out there to watch with your significant other.  Do NOT expect your husbands or bf's to tolerate this movie well....clearly it's aimed at the lonely, bitter, frustrated, or disillusioned female who has no clue what they want.

The scoring, by the way, featured some great classic songs, yet it was still terrible.  The music often didn't fit what was going on, or it was blended in weird, or it chopped the sound off abruptly at a good part of the song.

I got a little bored during this movie and also pissed off. I hate this notion that suddenly walking away from your American life and randomly wandering the world will give you an insight on what life is about. I hate to tell you but people in Italy and India are wondering the same thing. You're just filling your mind with new information which makes things exciting for a bit.

I had several conversations convincing my wife that we are NOT selling our brand new house and moving to the UK for a "simpler life."

Just.....Therapy or something.

I actually  watched this movie for the  first time in Cambodia  last year, and I absolutely  loved it!  Julia Roberts  shined in her role as Liz Gilbert .  I can relate  to the entire  soul  searching and having an appetite  for life.  Travel has fed my needs, but the only difference  is I am happily  married , and have  been  for almost  29 years .  My husband  and  I  travel  together , and have  for  years.  It takes courage  to  leave the  life you know behind, and suddenly  enter a new world  of uncertainty .  Liz never wanted to  hurt her  husband  by leaving  him, but she needed to be honest  with both him and  herself  as well.  Let yourself  go, and give this  movie  a chance; it is truly inspiring !

I've been wanting to watch this movie since it came out years ago - so I'm disappointed about having to write this negative review. The premise of the movie - like the book-  is great and it had a lot of potential. Unfortunately, it fell completely flat. There's no heart in this movie, the writing is campy, no depth in the characters except for their self-indulgence to the point of being whiny personalities from the first scene. It is so slooowwww moving that you can leave the room for 15 minutes to make a snack and not miss anything substantial. Generously, my husband and I lasted an hour into the movie hoping for the pivot -  but none came. Finally, we had enough and just gave up hope. If you're dying to see this movie, I would suggest waiting until it shows up on a free service so you can abandon it without guilt of having thrown a few of hard earned dollars to Amazon. Even the few dollars we paid for this rental was too much.

This movie is awful. The acting, the script, the way it was adapted from the book (scenes cut out, adapted). I listened to the audiobook and while I found the content kind of cheesy, the writing was decent and made it a worthwhile read for the commute home. The movie, however, included all of the terrible parts of the book and left out all of the promising aspects. Two stars because if you are really bored, it will at least help you kill time; if you are looking for something to equal the experience of the book this movie is not even palatable.

Julia Roberts is radiant in this film. She discovers there is more to life than a husband, house, and career. She finds a new appetite for life in this inspiring true story that is based on the best selling book. Enjoy the countries of Italy, India, and Bali with her as she discovers good food, meditation, and the prospect of finding true love.  Also stars James Franco, Billy Crudup, and Javier Bardem.  This perticular DVD has both the Director's Cut and the original Theatrical Version.

I really wanted to love that movie and thought it will inspire me but It didn't at all! A very pointless and meaningless movie! It tells a story of a selfish woman who had everything but she's unstable emotionally Just like a teenager who got changes in hormones and instead of her getting herself together by being busy, getting a second job or going back to school, she leaves her good husband whose only guilt is to be involved with a pathetic woman like her! She will seek another relationship with some young guy only to break his heart ... again!

My question here, do we all give Liz credit just because she's a woman? If that was a man, we'd have called him selfish, a**hole, j*rk... Oh you name it!

I'm a woman, working most of the day on my feet in a busy job..If I had an understanding, open minded husband like the one Liz had, then I won't do him like she did... She could have told him that she needs to travel but no, she divorced him instead!

"A foolish seeks happiness in the distance while a wise man grows it under his feet".... in other words, she didn't have to travel to Italy to eat Italian food, she could have bought Italian cookbook or go to Italian restaurants. She didn't have to travel to India to practice meditation, cuz all she had to do is take some yoga classes and/or practice meditation where she is. Finally, a person does not have to travel to a different country to seek love, come on now let's use common sense! Her reasons for traveling is stupid and awkward, I would love to travel myself but NOT to eat, pray and love but to have fun, and take selfies in new places.... My second question, what would Ms Liz tells those of us who are unable to travel? Sorry, that movie may fool a teenager who don't understand life but a grown up woman with a busy job and real life, no she would be the last woman on earth having my attention

It doesn't matter that this is not the greatest movie ever made, but it's high on my list.  Our world is in considerable need of a film like this.  The message is more profound than a cynical critic might believe.  I won't enumerate the details of the message.  Just look at it for yourself.  If you've seen it before, look again.  Please don't dismiss Julia Roberts as just a movie star doing her thing.  She's so honest and talented, you could miss her gift of herself to the film's truth.  This is also true of everyone else in the film. Everyone.  Richard Jenkins as usual hits it out of the park with his unbelievable surrender to the character. When he recalls his disappointment with himself revealing his loss of family caused by his recklessness, he made me totally believe, even though I'm a professional actor, writer and director who always knows the actor is not really the character.  Javier Bardem set aside his romantic, tough guy reputation to show us his vulnerability. He broke my heart. So did Jenkins. Credit for so much honesty among the actors must be shared by the director Ryan Murphy who established the environment for such truth telling. Of course, the original book by Elizabeth Gilbert and the film script by Murphy and Jennifer Felt were parents to this gorgeous child.  Even the ending which could be tossed away by "sophisticated" critics as a sappy happy ending is the heroine's reward for letting go of fear.  Not a bad lesson.  Look.  This a lovely, loving, rich film.  Aren't there more filmmakers out there - and bankrollers - who see how urgent it is for humanity - filmgoing human beings - to be lifted, reassured, inspired about the basic, underlying, overlying, spiritual facts of real life?  Is there anyone else out there who knows that films can be worthwhile and at the same time be beyond and above synthetic dramatical conflict, thrills, mayhem, anger, hatred, competition, destruction, killing?  Eat Pray Love looks at first glance like a lot of movies.  But it's not just another movie.  It's courageous, beautiful, and even entertaining.  Put that it your pipe, Hollywood.

I ordered Eat Pray Love. The DVD case said Eat Pray Love. The DVD said Eat Pray Love but the movie we received was The Martian. We were on vacation when we planned to watch this so were quite disappointed.

To address the reviews that said it was selfish; I believe that there are certain people who need a different, deeper, meaning in there lives. So many people, in all walks of life, get sucked into the factory-line of marriages that society seems to think you must participate in by the age of thirty. Some people (especially when married young) realize too late in the game that they followed along because it's what everybody does, because it was expected of them and not because it's what they really wanted. Yes, it's a horrible thing to realize for anyone involved but would it be fair to anyone to stay because society says you should, even though deep inside you know you were put on this earth to do other things? Isn't it worse to stay with someone and live a lie because you are afraid of what others will think or because you don't want to hurt anyone?

Not only does this story show how someone went against the grain, but it was an inspiration to those of us who seek more, to not be afraid of not fitting into the mold in which we think we must fit. It shows strength and courage to deeply love ourselves and to FINALLY put ourselves first before trying to meet the expectations of everyone else.

Although I never read the book on which it's based (my wife did), I felt this film suffered from a weak screenplay and weak preparation by Julia Roberts as the main character.  Javier Bardem and Richard Jenkins salvage the film, fairly late into it, with moving performances in supporting roles.

Julia Roberts's acting in this film was not as good as in other productions in which she has starred. It was as though she did not prepare for the role of embodying Liz Gilbert's character - perhaps she only read the weak screen adaptation and not the original book which I am assured by others established the main character and her situation better than the film.

The biggest weakness in the screenplay was that it failed to establish the main premise of the story - how Liz Gilbert had lost her sense of self every time she entered a romantic relationships - by showing, opting instead to convey that critical theme through the main character stating it as cold bare fact. Compounding this weakness was a severe lack of character development in either Liz's ex-husband Stephen, played by Billy Crudup, or even more so, in her first post-marriage boyfriend David, played by James Franco.

This was nevertheless an entertaining film, including some great foodie sequences (although I have to believe Italy offers more to eat than amazing pasta), and was ultimately rescued by the moving performances of Javier Bardem as Bali-based love interest Filipe, and Richard Jenkins as the painfully broken spiritualism seeker Liz encounters (and whose verbal insults she inexplicably tolerates) at a meditation retreat in India.

All American women go to therapists to discuss their bad relationships with weak American men.  Americans cannot find spiritual fulfillment in the U.S. so they must divorce their spouses and go globe trotting to poor countries where people are so much more real and in touch with what it means to be human.  Are you rolling your eyes yet?  It's okay for Americans to be spiritual as long as that doesn't involve traditional religions like Christianity.  There is a conversation about teachers in the U.S. - all the schools in the U.S. have gotten rid of art and music programs.  If they do have these programs, the art and music teachers must work for free!!!  Wow, how much influence did the teacher's unions have on the writers for that one? Marriage vows are unimportant to modern American women.  If American women are unhappy in their marriage, they should pack up and leave their broken-hearted husbands behind.  Then they should subsequently leave broken-hearted boyfriends behind because there will always be another gorgeous hunk right around the corner, that is if you are tall enough and skinny enough. Americans are really, really screwed up by capitalism and hard work, but they might have a chance for redemption if they go to enough gurus in the third world.  Ok, Hollywood, blah, blah, blah, yawn, yawn.  I can only enjoy looking a Julia Robert's big, toothy smile for so long!

She leaves her husband because suddenly she needs to find herself or "what to do" but moves in with this guy she barely knows and then decides to go travel the world I do not know what for, apparently she had endless amount of money to do so. This movie was pretty terrible.  I only gave it 2 stars because I like Julia Roberts & James Franco, but it's a pity they did this movie.  I have NOT read the book, but presumably it goes a bit deeper than the movie - one would hope, anyway, because the movie is a rather superficial summary of a life, wannabe spirituality, introspection, and love.

This movie and story is not really feminist, as one may want to believe.  It's just a seemingly spoiled woman who needs to convince herself it's ok to go enjoy stuff more and spend a lot of money on herself. Like - A LOT.  And apparently that was the key to her supposed 'enlightenment.'  I'm a middle-class white woman in NYC, so I'm not too far from understanding where she's coming from.  I understand for women it can be difficult to feel justified in giving yourself some time, attention, and love, and not feel like your selfish doing it, and it's totally legitimate for that to be part of your journey...however...this movie didn't capture the spirit of that true struggle for me at all.  And if she was supposed to have evolved throughout this to have gained more empathy for other people, they didn't do the best job at portraying that in a meaningful way, they just skimmed the surface of it.

The movie gives NO real back story, and doesn't go too deep into her psyche to understand why she is apparently suffering so much.  So, I basically developed ZERO empathy for her.  I didn't care about her 'quest' in any way, and it didn't seem to be that important.  We're all entitled to our experiences, and our feelings, but we shouldn't all be writing books and making movies about them...and then taking other people's money for them...(even if it was only the $2.99 for the SD version...I want my money back.)

Oh, you just can't seem to stay single for last 20 years?  You just can't stop having these pretty decent relationships that maybe aren't perfect but are with decent men?  Cry me a river.  What a nice problem to have.  And all this means you just haven't been able to spend time with yourself?  That's it?  Really?  Ok, then spend some time with yourself.  Oh wait - you have to completely change your life, go across the globe and spend thousands and thousands of dollars doing it, at some superficial attempt at enlightenment?  Oh cool.  Got it.

And then, when you've finally decided to know yourself better and find balance and various things that make you happy (yeah, hanging out in Bali partying and biking and chilling with your guru must be pretty hard introspective work!), then, and ONLY THEN can you learn the valuable lesson that it's ok to shirk all your "balance" and whatever else you care about to go spend MORE time with the new man you love (who you already hung out with for 2 weeks non-stop).  Oh yeah.  That's enlightenment.  Yes, getting a bit carried away with new love is totally legitimate. But to basically exalt this and tell yourself that it's ok to forget temporarily about all the things that got you supposedly "centered" in the first place kind of ruins that legitimacy.  Isn't that what she was running from in the first place?  That she was losing herself in someone else?

After having read the phenomenal book, I was disappointed in the movie and actually half way through it looked at the box to see how many minutes were left.  As great an actress as Julia Roberts is, she was not the right person for this role; a young Meryl Streep would have been more believable.  Liz Gilbert's personality in the book is bold and self-centered but was played by an actress who had to downplay her own bold, self-centered personality to become a self-pitying victim of her own misguided choices who had the fortune to travel to far off places to heal the pain of love gone awry.  The scenery was very realistic but maybe too realistic for a movie.  Less busy atmospheres with a calming effect would have made a greater impact but instead crowded the viewer's capacity to think.  On the bright side, the love interest and the guru were the highlights.

I've seen some scathing reviews on this movie, please don't listen to them. They must be expecting something other than what the movie is really about. For me, it was very inspiring, it helped me to also get through the soul searching I was experiencing at the time. The author was not self absorbed or frivolous, but trying to find her place in this chaotic world and her purpose in life in order to live as a better human being. The book goes deeper into this but the Hollywood version isn't so bad. You just need to know this is not a comedy romance, although it is fun and there is romance. Go into this with an open mind as well as a open heart.

Shallow and completely non-spiritual.  A perfect example of priv-lit egocentrism that gives true spirituality a bad name. This movie utterly repulsed me.  Why you ask?  Well try imagining it from the husband's perspective. If you do a little research you'll discover that while Ms. Gilbert was discovering her "true self," the husband she left was destroyed. To cope with his loss he immersed himself in actual humanitarian work...work that he had been doing for many years mind you. Could you imagine being dumped by your wife and then having her side of the story become a best seller - making her a millionaire!?  It would be as if the whole world agreed with her decision to divorce you.  Even worse - you get to watch her "struggle" with her decision to leave you on screen and hear her tell you to send her "light and love" in order to get over her.  Really?  That's what you got out of your trip to India?  And as if that wasn't enough, in the end you get to watch her "fall in love" with a dreamy Brazilian man - the capstone event of her enlightening year abroad.  So what's the moral of the story?  She "learned to love again."  Wow - I think I just threw up a little in my mouth.  So there you have it. If you wake up one day and find that the passion in your marriage is gone don't worry.  Happiness is found within - and maybe also in Bali.
Just the most perfect story, to help me get through a rough time in my life.

Who doesn't love Julia, and her love interest Javier is quite a charm; however, they are nothing like Elizabeth and Felipe from the story in the book.

 This as you know is a true story and when you read the amazing book Elizabeth comes off as quite humbled in the beginning because of a broken marriage and terrible divorce and decides to do an extended overseas travel starting in Italy.  Well in Italy Julia, still is Julia, and I really don't feel Elizabeths presence, Julia comes off as way too confident, (well Julia was 11 years Elizabeths senior) .  I wish they had an unknown actress play this role.
The movie is beautiful however felt rushed.

The next big taboo is that the character Felipe (in real life Jose) is suppose to be 17 years her senior!  But the actor Javier is one year younger then Julia!  How could they cast this?!! !  Nothing like the book, but if you watch it just as the movie is is a good movie.  Not 5 stars but good.

Beautiful study of a mature woman who faces a life without true purpose after two broken romantic relationships. She planned a trip and visits three different countries. First, she learns how to make peace with the world by making friends while enjoying meals and activities with them.  Then, in the second country she makes peace with the divine through prayer, meditation and introspection.  Finally in her last visit she makes peace with the archetype of the lover that this time shows up in a man that brings her the opportunity of true friendship and unconditional love.

This movie relates to many women and men for that matter in so many ways. I have seen this movie multiple times and I first saw it at a horrible time in my life.  It was the one thing that helped me to get back on my feet and realize that there is more to life.
So many people have said that this movie is boring, but I disagree.  I think that everyone nowadays scoffs at anything remotely spiritual and I think it is horribly sad.  This movie is all about finding yourself again when you have lost yourself so completely in another person that you don't know who you are.  Yes, she had a lot of money and could just drop her life and go on an adventure, but who doesn't fantasize about that?  This movie showed me that it is possible to get yourself out of a situation you are drowning in and you don't have to live in misery.
I hope that you take the time to read this and give this movie a try, especially if you are having a hard time in your life right now.  It saved my life - literally - and I know it will change yours too!

I borrowed this movie from a local library after hearing so many good comments about it. Perhaps we watched different movies, because I was was rather disappointed.

The story revolves around Liz, a woman who visits a medicine man that reads her palm and tells her about the future. She decides to take his information to heart and begins making major changes in her life based on this knowledge. She begins by divorcing her husband, a man with lots of ambition but lacks focus. She finds comfort in the arms of a younger stage actor but shortly after realizes it was more of a rebound relationship than anything.

In an attempt to figure out her priorities, she decides to take a year long trip through various locations hoping to find whatever it is she is missing. Her travels begin in Italy where she happens upon an English speaking Swedish woman at a local coffee shop. The two of them become friends and her social network in Italy begins expanding. Here she learns that sometimes doing nothing is alright, which is probably the best advice in the whole movie.

Next she moves on to India to visit a spirtual leader she became interested in while dating the actor/yoga instructor. This seemed rather odd because it seemed like she wasn't all that interested in the leader while dating her boyfriend, so why would she travel around the world to attend her retreat in a different country? Here she is able to forgive herself for the divorce and any other wrongdoings in her life.

The final locale is Bali where she reunites with the medicine man from the beginning and becomes his temporary assistant. He teaches her to find her balance in life, but ultimately tells her to forget the balance if she can find a love strong enough.

Maybe the book is better because it can dwell more on tiny details and personal reflections. The movie, however, came across as a woman who had a pretty good life (successful author, large circle of friends, and a caring husband) who decides she wants more/something different. It seemed very much like a man's mid-life crisis taken to the extreme. At least with a mid-life crisis you might buy an expensive car or "toy", but Liz decides to leave everyone she loves behind in order to go on a self imposed mission to discover herself mentally and spiritually. For the average person this type of "retreat" would not be monetarily obtainable, but due to her success she is able to shirk all obligations for an entire year.

I enjoyed watching this adaptation of the book of "Eat Pray Love."  The book includes more thoughtful insights from the author in a way that the movie format makes more difficult to provide.  As I thought that the details and thoughtfulness of the author's internal monologues, I guess you could call them, added some positive depth to the story, it is unfortunate that they were not much included in the movie version.  However, it still has enough in it to make it a fun and inspiring movie, with solid acting, beautiful settings, and many of the important scenes, characters, and realizations of the book.  If you want something a little more thoughtful than the usual chick-flick, you should check this out!

Ignore the bad reviews; people judge things they don't understand. This is not a romantic comedy, so while it can be funny and romantic, that is not its purpose. It's the hero's journey from myth, but with a female hero.

Nonattachment and choosing your own thoughts, subjects covered during her trip to India, are the key to happiness and are being taught in every spiritual discipline. Nonattachment is what spiritual teachers are teaching students right now. It's ironic in the best way that the attachment she ultimately had a hardest time giving up was her new dedication to nonattachment! She was terrified of wanting something again, and making a commitment.

She is not selfish for choosing the life she wants. As women we're taught that we're bad people if we don't dance to everyone else's tune. I thought it was the bolder choice doing what they did, maintaining the first husband's personality from the book, and making him not a bad guy. It was no one's fault, it just wasn't working.

I've been in her position, praying for something, anything, a way up off the floor. And education is almost always the answer. Yes, the fact that the character seemed to have a lot of money made her trips a lot easier but that's not a reason to be completely prejudiced against her. Starting with physical indulgence in Rome, exploring the power of pleasure, then turning completely spartan in India and concentrating only on the spirit, she had to find out if it was possible to do both -- to live in the modern world, enjoy herself, and maintain the spiritual life she needed. She got both, and the right man, in Bali.

This movie is perfect for anyone having hard times, someone exploring spirituality, especially meditation, Eastern religions, or simply anyone who really wants to travel. It hit me on all fronts. Watch it if you want to know more about having a larger life.
Lovely, funny and inspiring movie. It gave me hope for the future. I highly recommend it to anyone going through a divorce.
I could watch it over again. I  l love Julia Roberts in almost everything she does and this is no exception.
As with most films which are based on books, I think the book is better, but I still love this movie. It inspires me to travel and fully enjoy life instead of waiting for it to happen.

I wish this movie was better. You could only hope that a movie with such actors would be reasonably entertaining, amusing and/or likable. Unfortunately, the movie is not engaging and we frequently found ourselves asking "What?" and "Why"? When I learned that this movie was first a book, I realized its one of those movies that attempts to follow the book's storyline to a fault -- probably not satisfying fans of the book and leaving other viewers feeling like they missed something.  Probably the most disappointing aspect is that the main characters give you little reason to "root for them" and don't really have any development. It seems like Julia Robert's character is supposed to learn something, but in the end, you wonder if she's changed at all or moved forward in any way.

And the scenery, which seems to be noted a positive aspect of this movie by other reviewers, is nice, but given the material, and what other movies have done with the same settings, is boring. Poor cinematography?

This movie gets a single star, not because its the worst movie ever made (it isn't), but because it falls so short of modest expectations of entertainment and the potential (source material, actors, budget, etc.) for a good movie.

First, this is not a review of the movie; instead, this is about the DVD.
I chose the DVD because it is the most portable for all players in the household. The choices were either DVD or Blu-ray; no Blu-ray combo packs, Ultraviolet, or digital copies, therefore we had to go with the lowest common denominator for all player types from laptops to dedicated players.
The DVD does include both the theatrical version and the unrated director's cut, so this is at least some consolation. However, in this day of 'play anywhere anytime', this product does not measure up, even though it is priced the same as those that do provide more portability.
This is a great movie for a low-key girls night with a glass of wine and take-out.  Enjoy it girls!

So, I read the book (HATED IT) and couldn't get over how self-centered and awful the main character was.  Obviously, I was missing some big profound message or inspiration that has affected so many fans out there.  I just couldn't get past the fact that this woman was someone I did not like, that I would never be friends with, that I have absolutely no respect for!  That she was in Italy discovering a healthy relationship with food was preposterous!  Her story was vacuous and self-indulgent, and not really a story at all.  As for the interpretation of the movie, I hoped to find something that I missed in the book.  It was beautifully filmed but again, the character came across as ridiculous to me.  I like Julia Roberts and she did a decent job (I've seen her do better but this wasn't much of a role to sink anyone's teeth into).  I love Jarvier Bardem (LOVE) and he was a highlight for me... it's nice to see him in a vulnerable, romantic role rather than the villains that he's known for.  I just don't get the popularity of this rubbish and I usually enjoy deep, introspective movies/books!

I've read some excellent spot-on 1-star reviews here of "Eat Pray Love" that I couldn't really improve upon. The shallow, self-centered Julia Roberts character certainly deserves all the vitriol and criticism thrown her way in these reviews and I'm happy to see many are women. The sad thing is, this type of self-entitled solipsistic person really does exist. Don't think so? For a dose of grim reality, just read some of the 5-star reviews in which Roberts' character is seen as inspiring. What a sad existence it must be which leads one to see this character as a role model.

I loved reading the book.  It brought me to places, ideas, tastes, smells and feelings of each experience Elizabeth encountered.  It was nuanced with her challenges and internal struggles.  I was really looking forward to an evening with this movie and a glass of wine.

It made her awakening experiences trivial, her honest emotions sentimental. I could hardly bear to watch it.  A terrible script and poor casting choices.  Don't see the movie.  Read the book.
I enjoyed this quite a bit have watched it several times . The acting is good story is interesting the different settings I takes place in helps as well

Eat Pray LoveEat Pray and Love movie is entertaining. If you are the type of person that likes to fantasizes about the What ifs.... On life you will like it. It takes a lot of courage to just take of when one is not happy with their current situation, and this is what Julia R. Did on this movie. I saw myself in this movie. The book is better because it allows to see visualize the scenes the way one will like it.

I have read the book and while the movie is more "Hollywood" than the read, this is a must-see for anyone who has gone through, or is going through, major changes in life.  Inspirational, funny, and romantic.  Do not pass this up!

The view is beautiful, and it's not just Julia Roberts we're looking at; EPL is likely the best looking movie you'll see all year. Of course it helps to have Italy and Indonesia as exotic backdrops, but the art of cinematography should never be underestimated and it's really first class here; I'd go to Bali in a heartbeat, it looked that good.

If Julia Roberts went on a spiritual odyssey it might look a lot like EPL. OK, so we all know she's married with twins and gives every indication that she's happy with her lot, but it's actually not as far fetched a notion as it might seem. Apparently she found something to her liking in India whilst filming and embraced Hinduism on her return to New Mexico. Nice though that is, it's really the main problem with the movie.

The first time I heard someone call her Liz, as in Liz Gilbert, the real life protagonist on whose book the screenplay and movie are based, it was really grating. Towards the end it became less noticeable as she disappeared more into the role, but not much. I can't decide if she was miscast, or whether she was simply a necessity given the star wattage needed to make such an internally referenced movie.

Whilst the book is a chatty affair, a funny, self regalatory dialogue between reader and writer, a bit like listening in on an extended conversation between girlfriends, the movie usually side steps any effort to visually translate this and resorts to extensive use of voice-over. Perhaps a lesser star would have been more capable of disappearing into the role and carrying the weight of the emotional and spiritual journey. I'm not sure why but Naomi Watts keeps coming into my head as I think about it; from an acting point of view someone like her might been a better choice for the role because she has such a talent for raw emotion and for portraying neurotic and needy.

Having read the book a couple of times and got a lot from it, I had high hopes for the movie, but after reading a spate of poor reviews I realized I would have to downgrade my expectations. What really surprised me was how negative some of the reviews were; some reviewers really hated the movie and these were reviewers whose opinions I normally seek out and respect. They viewed Liz Gilbert as selfish and self indulgent in the extreme and whilst they may have a point, I think the problem was that they hadn't read the book. Lacking the time to really delve into the reasons for her journey, the movie portrays her as very self seeking in her treatment of the men she left behind. For this reason I almost felt it would have been better to simply launch her straight into the Italian section of her journey and fill in the missing motivation and back story as necessary.

Apparently the director and co-writer Ryan Murphy consulted with Elizabeth Gilbert on the screenplay and as a result was able to include material not in the book, even as he had to leave much out. This led to incidents like one just before the movie ends where Julia (sorry, Liz) breaks off her relationship with her Brazilian amour Felipe because she fears it will undermine everything she has sought during her year of exploration, namely balance. Whether this actually happened seemed beside the point; it seemed true to the spirit of her journey and I wished more liberties had been taken in an attempt to get to the heart of the story. With a distinct lack of such resonant moments the movie usually seemed more interested in outer beauty than in portraying her struggle for inner peace.

It's a well accepted truism that books and movies are apples and oranges; the movie of a book has to stand alone as a complete entity in itself and this usually means staying true to the spine of the book but substantially reinventing how that is portrayed in this most visual of mediums. It seemed to me the movie lacked the confidence to do this, probably as it didn't want to offend the book's many fans.

Having said all that I'm sure the movie will do well, even if it never expands its audience beyond the 8 million readers who bought the book. But whilst the book led to legions of devoted Liz followers (known by some as Lizbians) and touched a nerve somewhere deep in the psyche of many middle aged women seeking reinvention, the movie leaves its audience with nothing of substance. It was probably too much to hope that it would, but it's sad nevertheless that a book that held such meaning for so many should be reduced to nothing more than a 2 hour diversion in a movie theater.

EPL is the consummate "chick flick". The theme is that of a young woman searching for inner self and how she learns about life while traveling around the world. The locations are great visually but the characters are saccharin sweet. The ending was fairly predicable. I would not watch this show again, let alone pay for it, but my wife liked it. I can tell because she actually managed to stay awake for the entire program.

This movie should make you pause a moment and encourage you to reflect on what is important in your life rather than continuously accepting that routine is life.  Humans are multifaceted; we're not just our job, parent, husband, or child.  We're many things, and it's important to give time and focus to that variety.
First time I tried to watch it I fell asleep. But the next 6 times I fell in love with story, cast, scenery and whole concept of getting away to renew yourself.  Watch it and enjoy.

This is a woman's unique journey of learning how to love out of generosity, not sacrifice.

Gilbert, like so many young American women, commit themselves too early to a direction/relationship in life. After all she grew up in a very traditional, middle class, mid-western family (who often define happiness as a traditional marriage and planted lifestyle in your 20s). And she held onto to this life for a long time, because like all women, she didn't want to hurt anyone. But many young American women need to figure out who they are before committing to a husband and a life. This takes time and emotional maturity many women are taught to believe they do not have.

Why? Building a life not based on your unique passions and understanding of the kind of husband who is right for you is frankly...wrong.  This means you will spend your life loving others by giving from your root and not your fruit. And in the long run, yes it hurts us, but it ALWAYS HURTS OUR LOVED ONES.

Gilbert married into the wrong relationship for her. She couldn't accept him as he was. She was dependent on him being someone he wasn't.  When we don't feel good about ourselves and our lives, we struggle to love others well. "Do you feel my love for you?" as Elizabeth said. So by the time most women hit their 30s, they realize living a life where you're tolerating misery isn't good for anyone.

Truly loving people means there are no strings attached...because believe in the authenticity of our love for them BASED ON HOW WE LOVE OURSELVES. When we are content and at peace with ourselves, then we can really GIVE to others without NEEDING back from them.  That's how our love empowers others...which is the greatest way to live.

But to change your life so you give from your fruit and not your root is often a MESS.  But Gilbert had the courage to do it.  If she had not let her husband go, he wouldn't have had the chance to make a happier life. What a risky, loving, and brave thing to do.

So I find the principles in Eat Pray Love incredibly relateable to every woman who decides to un-compromise her life for the sake of making the world a better place.

Eat Pray Love is the movie based on the novel of the same title by Liz Gilbert. Julia Roberts is very god at playing the fragile, tearful female, but it is difficult to capture a work with such a lot of inner monologue on film. Still, Liz Gilbert comes across as self-indulgent and self-centred in the movie, just like she does in the book. It's a good screenplay and well-acted: just a pity to waste such a lot of effort on a mediocre novel.

The plot revolves around a selfish, unhappy woman who decides to travel to Italy and India to "find" herself and discovers others who have problems of their own. Had she been traveling to suburban America, it would've been a 1 star movie.

SPOILERS:

I'm not sure if Julia Roberts' character simply chose the wrong person to marry or really didn't want to be married to anyone, but thought she had to be. She's a career woman, who finds it beneath her to have children, which should have been discussed with her fiance before marriage. She should have told him she didn't want to have kids, which was one reason she filed for divorce.

She also was upset that her husband wanted some home-cooked meals. Again, if she hated cooking, she should have told him before getting married to him, such as, "I hate cooking, so if you want a home-cooked meal, be prepared to do it yourself." Cooking is a responsibility that can be shared as well, but she felt it necessary to divorce over that issue too.

Then she decides everything is about her and what she wants, never mind what her husband wants. But he's not entirely innocent either, because she talks, and he doesn't listen. Both of them needed to sit down and discuss what they wanted out of life and what they wanted from each other before getting married.

So to make herself feel better she travels, meets people, and gets happy. Who wouldn't be happier after spending a year's long vacation without worrying about the cost?

I couldn't see a difficulty when she's trying to break up her marriage to Stephen so much.
David who played a main part of Liz's book on stage was cool and sweet.
How could she dump him, even though he hadn't slept with her for a while.
I like the india's song for the morning pray.

She might have been crazy a little at the time, because of the divorce.

She left David to Italy.
Scenaries are good.

Her boyfriend's family was nice. his dad gave Liz a speech like a summon.
She has hanged out with the Swedish woman and his family in Italy.

She moved to India to go to an ashram that somebody that David has admired lives in to meet her and stay at for a while.
The Sunset with building like musulim's charch looks beautiful.
She met an indian girl and Robert there.
Liz and the girl often have a chat about a boyfriend or something like that.
Liz couldn't have focused on the meditation till she talked with David on the phone.
Before he's back, Robert confesses about his past and his family that he has separated with.
and He let Liz go to the indian couple's wedding with him.  Liz remembers her wedding party.

She finally moved to Indonesia.
She went to see Ketut though, he didn't remember Liz for a while.
One day, She met a guy. She stayed with him... foever??? as Ketut suggested her again???
How could she make up her mind?

I hardly understand Liz.

Shallow and self centered and in the end misses the opportunity to be inspired.

In conclusion to the search, this lovely, supposedly enlightened women, still needed a man to feel complete or okay.  The message being no matter how successful and beautiful, a women needs a man.

Eat, Pray, Love is a true story about a writer who leaves her husband because she's overcome with the feeling that her life doesn't fit and isn't a real reflection of herself. She seeks escape in a younger man, doesn't find it, then decides that she may have better luck by doing a yearlong adventure in Italy, India, and Indonesia. Through those adventures she finds love and happiness again.

I have mixed feelings about the movie. I read the book and felt it was a self-indulgent pity party. I didn't expect much from the movie, but wanted to give it a chance.

CONS:
Julia Roberts is horrible. I am not a Roberts fan, but seeing her in this was agony. I am so over her. She can't act. Period. She is the same in everything. Was this Erin Brockovich Goes to Italy or Julianne Porter (from My Best Friend's Wedding) Shacks Up? She looked depressed most of the time. When she lit up, it was a huge contrast, but that rarely happened. The only way I knew that she had transformed into a happy person was when the Balinese man (Ketut) said so.

The pace was REALLY fast. I knew that there had to be a lot left out in order to cover adventures in three countries and give it a set up as well, but this was lightning speed. It didn't give a chance to really get the flavor of each location or how she was changed by the experiences there. We are just given dialog that tells us what happened. The segues from place to place were abrupt too.

The ah ha! moments didn't translate to film. The first one was, "Go to bed, Liz." That wasn't illuminating to me in the book either, but I could see how she thought it was. In the film, it was as if God was not listening to her. All of the big turning points in the book were lost in the movie.

It's unrelatable. It feels like a fantasy. "Normal" people just don't cry over nothing, run off for a year, forget all their friends, and come back happy. I think that is the big message of the movie and that falls flat...unless that is your fantasy.

PROS:
Despite all I just said, I actually "got" that her inner/outer journey was transformative. Maybe that was because I read the book. Maybe it's because I lead sacred travel tours and have experienced that same growth myself. Some of the things that may have seemed trite and New Age resonated with me. (Maybe because I'm trite and New Age? lol)

The scenery was the big winner. As a world traveler myself, I LOVE, LOVE, LOVE seeing new places. The locations weren't just shot as background. They were characters in the movie! That was very effectively done. Of the three locations, I have only been to Rome, but it IS everything you see and more!

I hate when people can't review a product for what it is instead of comparing it to the book because often, I haven't read the book. Sorry for doing that to you. If you haven't read the book and are wondering whether to try it out, my advice is, if you like Roberts, the Hollywood formula and exotic locales, you will probably like it. If you want meaning, logic and good acting, forget it. :)

I'm not a prude, a chauvinist, or delusional, as my old reviews will prove. This book is irrelevant because 99.9% of men will never read it.  A 45 year old in rapid succession: divorces against her husband's pleas, rushes into bed with a new guy whom she quickly hates  Then she travels around the world, eating 10,000 calories a day without gaining an ounce, embraced by crowds of loving warm new friends, confided in and mentored by wise old men, and rushed into a 2 week sex marathon by a Brazilian stud with a heart of gold.  Yes ladies, celebrate all your crazy decisions.  A long string of male mentors and lovers will magically fix you.

I thoroughly enjoyed the audio book narrated by Liz Gilbert, and I'm a Julia Roberts fan, so watching the movie seemed like a good idea.  Unfortunately, this movie adaptation is really, really awful.  I forced myself to watch up to the weeping Richard scene at the ashram.  That was the final straw; totally out of character and not in the book.  Do yourself a favor, read the book and forget the movie.
I haven't walked out of many movies in my life, but this was one of them...  Dreary, meandering, pointless and even more self-indulgent than the book, this film was truly awful.

If you are looking for a feel good movie about love, food and friendship, then search no further.  A great movie to watch alone or with a friend. It will make you laugh and cry and if you are a Julia Roberts fan, bonus!

I usually don't watch a movie based on a book I really like because it is almost always disappointing. Even though so much of the wonderful background had to be left out, the movie did a great job of fleshing out the characters.  I thought the casting was brilliant.  Only Roberts could have pulled off this part and made it believable.  Her non-classic beauty and charisma can make one believe that a single, non-wealthy woman could plunge into three different cultures and find the best and brightest.

I preferred the novel to the movie. At times, the movie felt shallow, and self-absorbed.

There are a few problems with this story (love it or hate it); but at the end of the day, it's a one woman's journey. Everyone is different.

Javier was fun to watch (and sexy, as always) but I'm not sure Julia Roberts was the rights cast for this character. She seemed too cold and distant; I didn't really see the chemistry between them.

But, I enjoyed the locations, the cinematography was superb, and it inspired me to travel more (and that's good) . . . I'm going to Italy this summer.

I think the story is about taking a stand for you own life. Do the things you need to do. This, to me is an important message women need to hear more often.

A movie to watch with your girlfriend, a glass of wine; if . . . you're preparing for a trip to Bali or Italy.
This movie is by far one of the best movie I have ever seen. At first it seems like a "chick flick" but the message behind it can easily apply to everyone.

I watched the movie and was so intrigued by it, I went and bought the book. I have learned how to appreciate my life because it is somewhat similar to the setting of her journey. I especially learned how to forgive people & let go of bad tastes. It's just a book & a movie but I connected very deeply  with it in a good way.
Brande new, great price, fast delivery.  And it takes me around the world to amazing places.  The movie leaves out some of the information from the book but I have enjoyed both.

It is a fun travelogue and quest as Elizabeth (Julia Roberts) leaves her familiar world to spend time eating, praying and learning to love again.  I admired the character's willingness to leave the conventional and explore the world - do something different and get out of her rut after her marriage failed.  Enjoyed the book more, but it was fun to see it come to colorful cinematic life. 3.5 stars

I know it's unusual (people usually prefer the book to the film), but in my case I found that Julia Roberts, Javier Bardem, and others actually brought some color and life to the characters in the book.  In the book, I didn't actually like either of these characters, but Julia and Javier caused me to like them more.

Much of the photography (especially in the Balinese sequence) is really quite beautiful.

Like many movies before it, EPL is a film about "finding one's self".  Fortunately there are better examples than this story of a woman (Julia Roberts) who realizes her marriage is a sham, gets a divorce then shacks up with a young actor (James Franco).  Na, this doesn't feel right either, so she puts her belongings in storage (what no furniture?) and heads out for a year long journey to Italy, India and Bali.  It's hard to feel too sorry for her.  How many of us could take a sabbatical like that?  She can, as she is a successful writer and speaker about the human condition.  The film is beautifully shot but seems to lack the heart and soul and emotional depth we chick flick types look for.  The movie isn't a total failure however.  The acting is fine; the music is really good, ranging from some nice Brazilian stuff to vintage Neil Young.  The best parts of the movie are where Liz (Roberts) writes her letters or otherwise narrates her feelings.  These are beautifully written, I suspect straight from Elizabeth Gilbert's book.
Quick reunion with a well-loved movie; Amazon could almost be Match.com! Brings faraway places right into your living room and heart.
As I love to travel myself, I couldn't pass up purchasing this movie. Great movie at a great price!Eat, Pray, Love - One Woman's Search For Everything Across Italy, India And Indonesia

I read the good and the bad reviews before watching this movie, and not one of them spoke of the spiritual journey of healing and forgiveness which this movie address beautifully.
I am buying this movie and will watch it again.
Wonderful movie about a woman trying to find her passion for life by spending a year going to different locations in the world.  Very honest and thoroughly enjoyable to watch.

Alright, I know this is a total chick flick and I was hoping at least the parts where Julia Roberts's teeth showed up would be good enough. Yet not even her enormous mouth can save this mess.

You can fast-forward the first 29 minutes or so as it's all slow back story. I did not and now I'll never get those 29 minutes of my life back.

Now once Ms. Roberts lands in Italy the movie starts to come to life. The friends she makes in Italy and the scenarios involving food, gestures, joining soccer fans in Napoli and exploring Rome make for a fantastic movie. That movie I wanted to see.

Sadly, as soon as that gets started it's over and off to India. Landing in India we get that helter skelter taxi cab ride through the bizarre culture shock that is the Asian subcontinent. Then the movie reverts back to slow as molasses boredom in an ashram. Sorry, I just cannot handle navel-gazing hippy nonsense. That whole section of the flick I did fast-forward.

Then onto Bali where the story of Julia's journey actually started in the "fillum." There it's pretty much hit and more miss as Javier No Country and her start a romance that is fine for what it is but involves way too much neurosis on Julia's part.

So I'd say overall Eat is excellent, Pray is hideous and Love is just mediocre. Personally, I would have liked to have dumped Julia and stayed in Rome to follow her close friends--the Swedish woman and her Italian boyfriend. Now they were an infinitely more interesting couple than No Country for Bali and Erin Bali-no-vich.

DVD has a director's cut and a making of extra with the director going on and on about how wonderful this tale was. Whatever, sell the movie to the converted who love the book but as one who did not read the book, this is not a good movie on its own. At least the scenery is most of the places was good to look at.

Perhaps the best compliment I can give the film "Eat Pray Love" is that it is not nearly as bad as I expected it to be, based on comments both at this site and from respected film critics.  Julia Roberts does an admirable job portraying a self-involved woman who clearly only thinks of herself.  She does show some personal growth in her year of finding herself, but ultimately, the movie left me with kind of a blah feeling, like I wanted more positive change in our protagonist (I realize this is a true story).

My wife loved the book and film, and as a middle-aged male, I suspect I wasn't the demographic they were interested in anyway when marketing this film, as I only watched it with my wife as a personal favor.  So, it could have been worse, but I clearly do not recommend watching this film if you are a middle-aged male, unless you want to keep the better half happy that you can actually stop watching the gosh-darned sports for a couple of hours and share a gosh-darn film that she actually wants to see, (for once).
This DVD had a huge scratch on it and doesn't work at all. I could never get it to play and I was extremely discontent with this product.

Julia Roberts stars in the movie based on Elizabeth Gilbert's bestselling memoir. I haven't read the book, so I can't say how true the film is to the book. I can tell you that the scenes of Italy, India, and Bali make the film fun to watch.

After a divorce and another failed relationship, Gilbert walks away from her life to explore the sensual pleasures of Italian food. Her next stop is an ashram in India where she develops her spirituality. She ends her travels in Bali to reconnect with a healer she had met in New York.

Gilbert's real life journey comes with a Hollywood ending. Lots of good messages along with a happy ending.

I have loved everything Julia Roberts has been in, up to Eat Pray Love.  The story line is a common theme; Someone cheating in a marriage, feeling lost, needing to leaving it all behind to  find oneself.  Javier Bardem was great in the part, what a hottie. But Julia, She lacked something that I was looking for in her character.

I saw this movie at the theater and then bought the book. I am still reading through that, but since then have bought the dvd to remember the visuals from each place she visited. The music was great and the topics covered are serious and things we sometimes never dig deep enough to explore, yet they affect us just the same. I would recommend this to anyone dealing with crisis. The openness of the guy at the end with his kid just made it really hard to resist and there is a happy ending.
I was a bit disappointed in this movie as Julia Roberts is one of my favorites, however this was slow getting into, maybe just too much deepness with out enough fun and action.

Much has been said about this movie not being nearly as good as the book, and that is all nonsense.  The book is a monologue and since when have you gone to the cinema to see a movie with almost no dialogue, just one person talking?  Would you really want to watch a woman in the midst of a nervous breakdown, constantly screaming and weeping, all "ME ME ME, WHY ME"?  Most folks would not, and would say she needed to get her act together, which is what the book is about.  The movie hardly mentions that part.  Some books, like "Room With A View" make it to the screen almost entirely intact and watching the (Merchant Ivory) movie is like seeing the beloved book brought to life.  Other books, like "Under The Tuscan Sun" end up with a movie that bears no resemblance to the book, because the book wasn't that good to begin with.  "Eat Pray Love" is something else.  Bits and pieces of the book are cherry picked and a movie was made, with characters invented to give a home to parts of the monologue now repurposed as dialogue.  Almost nothing in the movie happens in the way it was written in the book, but we get an entertaining romantic comedy with some spiritual mumbo-jumbo, and without all the gut wrenching self loathing, and mental melt down.

We also get some fairly gorgeous cinematography, particularly in the Italy and Bali sections.

Unfortunately, it seems that quite a bit of the film ended up on the editing room floor which makes some parts of the film seem like they need a bit more explaining, something that is far more clear if you've read the book, but not essential to the enjoyment of this film.

I have now enjoyed the book, and will still enjoy the movie as I found it, a romantic comedy/a "chick flick".  To all those who are hysterical that we didn't get a film about a neurotic, screaming, control freak alternately discovering the pleasures of the world and how to actually live in it I say, Bah.  Bah!

I just read the book and went right out and got the movie hoping that it would enhance my experience reading the book.  I am so disappointed.  The book is funny and the people are likable.  This movie is heavy, slow and so sad.  I was bored and a few times so tired of Julia Roberts (even though I like her).  This is a hollywoodtised book/movie that does not work. Sorry, I really wanted to like it.  Loved loved the book.

I loved the book. It touched me deeply. I have read it, listened to the audio book (like 10 times), and bought many copies to give to friends. It was the story of a spiritual journey and a woman's search for survival, emotional health, and balance. It rang true and the characters were believable and real. (Especially Richard from Texas!) The book never touched on anything even vaguely resembling depth or spirituality. It was fluffy, disjointed, and an insult to the book. I so looked forward to seeing it and was SOOOOO disappointed in this pitiful, fragmented movie.

Okay, I didn't read the book, but whatever magically transformative life journey this Liz character truly experienced certainly does not come across in this film. Everything feels utterly staged, phony, and artificial. The acting is boring. The storyline is boring and the flow is painfully choppy (now we eat. now we pray. now we love). This directing is horrendous (did we really need all the closeups of Julia Roberts eating spaghetti? Okay, I get it. This is the "eat" part). I am glad to see I'm not alone for a change in bashing a bad film.  Several scenes just made me wince at the insincere, artificial quality. The character does come off seeming a like a spoiled princess who thinks this weather-beaten old spirtitual advisor character can help transform her life. Sorry not buying it. Please please please! No more tedious, predictable, stale films like these. One star for James Franco for the eye candy value.

Maybe I am too simple in what I expect from a movie. I just want a temporary diversion, an escape. This was the reason movies were more or less invented, to divert people's attention from the woes and horrors of everything going on during the Depression and WW II. Today there are plenty of problems in America that make a movie like this one great entertainment, for me at least, to get away from tornadoes, forest fires, drought, floods and unemployment, to name a few.

I laughed a lot at the predicament of trying to learn a new language (Italy) and customs of India. Right away I am in Amazon looking up the movie to buy. Who cares about the deep under currents and subplots. I am 72 and I want entertainment. I laughed and I cried. That to me makes a movie that I would want in my movie library, to watch again and again.

P.S. A movie is like a restaurant meal. Some are good, some are not so good. If I don't like the food I don't have to eat it. I know other places that make food. The same goes for a movie. I know where to rent more movies. Why waste time on creative criticism?
Loved this movie!  I had read the book and loved it too, but Julia and Javier made it even better.

Julia Roberts character starts the movie married.  He is totally devoted to her but she looks at him with total contempt from the beginning.  The first part of the movie is about her mid-life crises.  She feels trapped and wants to selfishly abandon her husband to travel the world.  Despite everyone around her telling her she is acting like a teenager or early twenty year old, she divorces her husband.  In the divorce proceedings he even turns down all her money and says he just wants her; he also laments she never told him she was unhappy, just left (she instantly starts sleeping with a much younger man-I mean instantly).  She then leaves to go and do what the movie should be called, "Eat, sleep with Younger Guys and Be Selfish"  How many women would love this movie if the main character was a man?  What if the man instantly left his wife and started sleeping around?  He would be a "pig" and they would hate the move.  Falling in love is easy, staying in love is hard; it takes work.  With "Hollywood" role models guiding so much of our life, I wonder why our divorce rate is 50%?
You'll cry, you'll laugh, and you'll love it!  This is a great story with great actors, creating a great movie.  Guys, your significant other is sure to love it, and you'll enjoy it too!

I didn't hate it.  I do find it difficult when American actors agree to dialogue that attempts to state American stereotypes as fact.  Apparently the American idea of fun is to drink too much and then spend every evening in front of the idiot box...mmm, not terribly accurate.  The story is uninteresting.  It seems that Liz in incapable of being alone, period.  She seems to have a bad habit of expecting others to fulfil her happiness, she doesn't seem to have the ability to do the work and find it on her own.  Therefore, she inevitable ends up miserable and can't seem to figure out why.  She is a moron.  I will give credit to Roberts for allowing herself to be dumpy through almost the entire film.  And she is no longer trying to NOT use her trademark laugh, which is nice.  Overall, if I had the resources to do what she did, I would have spent my time more wisely.

I bought this movie w/o ever having seen it before.  Surprised to like it better than the book.  The book was like living my own struggle over again so the movie much more pleasant!  Beautiful scenery too.

Julia is way old and oh god this movie is so freakin bad I cannot even begin to start.

avoid at all cost!!

bad acting...horrid evil vile yikes

I really like this movie it gives me such a peaceful feeling. Yes there is practically no actions in this movie, like other reviewers were complaining, but I think this is a point - no action, just self-realization.
I like show on PBS: As time goes by, it gives me similar feeling and there is no much action either.
I think you just have to relax and smell the roses.
I also impressed by Julia Roberts performance, I think that she really grew up as an actress.

I was actually quite impressed with this film, particularly in its depiction of India.

The film is very open minded and, when following Julia Roberts's character, does not make strong judgements about places or people.

My favourite part of the film was when the main character was in India and she meets Richard, an American with a dark secret. Its quite touching when he opens up and Elizabeth listens attentively without judging him.

I'm surprised at how many bad reviews this film is getting. Julia Roberts gives a great performance in what is a light hearted film about changing the course of your life. We're not being told to subscribe to the theory on display in the film, but simply to sit back, enjoy and consider some of the things being discussed.

Personally, I thought it was great, light entertainment that has a heart. I'm also ordering a copy of the book as I type:)

Very enjoyable.

Thanks for crapping all over a story about growth, healing, enlightenment, and love, and turning into the same old boring flick we've seen a million times, Hollywood. The interesting spiritual stuff is gone, even the food parts are uninteresting. I don't really buy the love story at all. This movie has some elements of the book, sure, but none of the depth.

I hesitated to watch this. It was on Netflix, so I figured I'd give it a go, since I don't have to pay any more for it. Yeah, bad idea. For gutting the story like it did, it was way too long. The scenery wasn't as cool as it should have been, and the characters other than Gilbert were not explored at all, let alone as deeply as they were in the book.

Okay, fine, I get that's what Hollywood does. However, this was an autobiographical work. These were real people who got turned into props. Gilbert's own amazing and inspiring spiritual journey got totally pushed to the backseat. She does some emotional work in the movie, but all of the spiritual enlightenment, which is a beautiful and amazing story in and of itself, is gone.

Elizabeth Gilbert is a real person, and I just don't think she deserves to be portrayed as a shallow idiot with no introspection. Especially after she went through the spiritual work and was wonderful enough to share that with the rest of us by writing it down in her book.

Really, just take the time to read the book.

This movie incorporated all the goodness, peace, and longing for a happy life that we all seek. It was nothing like the movies of today that are filled with sex, violence, and horror. It is an exceptional movie!!!

Inspiring!!

Julia Roberts plays the role of a heartbroken divorced women who decides to travel to Italy, India, and Indonesia to find inner peace and balance. She goes on a 1 year journey traveling to these 3 countries searching for happiness.

I was inspired by the quote given by Ketut: "In order to stay happy, you must always know where you are". If you do know your place in the journey of life, you will accept everything that happens to you and will have inner peace, eventually becoming happy.
