I believe this could simply be done by grabbing a piece of paper and write/draw on it your journey through life. Put on it life's basic elements such as success, love, family, spirituality, health...etc. See where you are. See the big picture. See which areas you need to improve and perfect. Hang this paper somewhere in the house and look at it everyday. Keep thinking about it, and I believe this is how you could achieve inner peace and balance.

I heard people criticize this movie for being slow and sometimes boring. Well, the pace of the movie MUST be slow since its about achieving inner balance. You can't expect a fast paced movie about inner balance to be effective and received well. It has to be slow and need to take its time, just like the journey for the quest of happiness.

Good movie, I highly recommend it.

The movie was good for its entertainment value such as: beautiful scenes of italy, bali and india, her unique outfits, and just an excuse to be lazy and watch someone else travel. So overall it was nice, just not realistic.

Now for the bad part. Its sooo fake. Its like a fairytale. Here's what they try to make us believe:
1) MONEY IS OPTIONAL
She allegedly got divorced and had no money. But yet, she manages to take a trip to 3 countries and stay there for several years?? Not once did she even get a job to support herself. She stayed in pretty nice places for it to be "free". She even had money to take italian classes from a hot tutor.

2) DESIGNER CLOTHES
How did she have the money? How did she have the time to go shopping? I didn't see her go shopping. Her wardrobe was very nice despite the fact that she only traveled with "one little bag". Not realistic at all! For a girl to carry such a small bag with  barely any clothes or makeup, they would not look like julia roberts who would wake up freshly made up and with perfect boticelli curls. And we cannot forget how clean she looked while in India and Bali.

3) GIRLS ARE SO NICE AND EASY TO MAKE FRIENDS WITH
Not! In real life, girls couldn't care less about other girls. But in this movie, she makes girlfriends easily. And in all the cases, they approached her. She didn't have to do any effort. Its as if they knew she was the celebrity "julia roberts" even though shes "acting" like someone else. I'm sorry but in real life, girls are catty as can be!

4) LIFE IS PERFECT WHEN YOU TRAVEL
Nothing annoying or bad happened to her while she traveled. She wasn't mugged. She didn't really have a bad day. Things always worked out for her. That's not realistic. The only time something "bad" happened ended up being "good", like hurting her leg to meet the guy of her dreams.

5) GURUS ARE WAITING AROUND TO HELP WHITE AMERICAN GIRLS FIND THEMSELVES
Im not really sure what his intentions were. Exactly how was he benefiting from this relationship? Was he that lonely that she was his only friend? She only brought stress to the guru.

6) GAINING WEIGHT IN THE MOVIE MEANS WEIGHING 125LBS
The girl she met in Italy was complaining about gaining weight and she was so skinny. So they set out on a journey to find bigger jeans...whoa thats a great story. If that girl is fat, then I must be obese. I was laughing out loud when they were both in the dressing room trying to close her size 4 jeans on her obviously tiny body. It was sooo ridiculous because the jeans obviously fit her tiny ass. But they kept acting like she was the girl in the movie "Precious".

7) MEN ARE LINING UP
For us normal looking folk, men don't just appear the way they appear in this movie. If i  went to a crowded play, i certainly would not catch the eye of the lead character. 1) because its crowded 2) because i don't look like julia roberts
This movie is just an insight on what its like to be beautifully attractive.

8) WHAT THE HELL WAS SHE LOOKING FOR? DID SHE EVEN FIND IT?
I still don't know what she wanted in the first place. I mean, i just thought she wanted a long vacation. But isn't that what everyone wants? We just don't have the money like she did. She claimed she wanted peace. But how exactly? In the form of a man? I thought the movie would be a little deeper than that. I think she was just bored the whole time.

9) POOR LIZ, HER LIFE WAS SO AWFUL BEFORE THE TRIP!
They didn't convince me that her life was so bad before
She was in a mansion, friends, her cute husband, what was the problem? Well, they didn't really show it if there was one. If it was an issue of editing, there were many other parts of the movie that i would have sacrificed so that they could add a scene about why she hated her life so much.

10) LIZ WAS VERY RESPONSIBLE TO LEAVER HER MARRIAGE OF 8 YEARS SO ABRUPTLY
I wonder if she even had a heartbeat. She didn't give him a chance to fix it. And she left halfway around the world. I don't think he was that bad. She acted like he abused her or something.

11) SHE'S NOT INDEPENDENT, BUT SHE THINKS SHE IS.....
Yeah, she did make the trip halfway around the world, BUT, she only makes decisions based on the guru/medicine healer's opinion. In the end, she has no mind of her own.

12) LACK OF CHARACTER DEVELOPMENT
james franco (david), richard and her husband didn't really have good character development. They all just disappear into the void.
13) How did Felipe fall in love with her so fast?
They barely just met. I can't figure this one out. Was it because felipes son told his dad that its time he have sex again?

14) POOR & MIDDLE CLASS AMERICANS CAN'T HAVE ENLIGHTENMENT
Why? Because we don't have the money to take years off our jobs and go to 3 countries and go on vacation.
15) The guru/medicine healer really needed subtitles. I tried hard to understand a word he said.

16) THE TITLE OF THIS MOVIE SHOULD HAVE BEEN "SELFISH AROUND THE WORLD"
Liz is selfish, not because she is trying to find herself but because of the way she is with other people in this movie. She doesn't think of others while she is trying to find herself. They tried to make her seem so nice by giving the house to the family, but that was the only nice gesture. She didn't care about anyone else 's feelings.

HERE'S WHAT THE MOVIE HAS TO OFFER:
1)A scenic break from our mundane lives that last about 2 hours.
2)It will make you think its time to go on vacation.
3)Will make you want to cook or eat italian food
4)Its fun to make fun of this unrealistic movie

But that's all it is. Other than that, it was entertaining and i love julia roberts charisma and charm.
But don't expect to find your own enlightenment here.

I notified this company within the time frame they failed to responed and now I stuck with a movie that does not work. I bought this film for my mom. I should of went to target and just bought the film. Now the company wants to say I never contacted them or within the amount time. Defected material is defected material. I order alot from this website and so do alot of people I know. I would rather pay full price or go to a store then purchase from people who sell defective materials.

Im so SHocked by the negative reviews. Now this movie may not satisfy those looking for some crazy scenes of wild action, violence and r rated sex that seems to be the desired film content for the simple of mind, but it was the perfect movie of peace and self direction. The scenery was beautiful and the casting was great. You leave this movie feeling like you can breathe a little easier. I guess people don't like movies with a point anymore...or ones about self discovery, self creation and finding out who you are beneath the surface. I bought this and watch it every time my life gets a little tougher. I really liked this movie and what it had to offer...i hope you do too.

"Wild Horses in Mongolia"? you ask. The point is that like her Mongolia documentary Julia in "Eat ..." shows her intelligence and courage in tackling domains and subjects that most of us would rather avoid. Yes, it was a bit too artificial and polished. Very much a producer's dream immense film production. It might have been better served to have Julia more naturally explore the topics discussed in the book. By analogy comparable to a college student's worldly exploration and discovery after dropping out of school for a year as opposed to the film's Costco travel agency programmed life experience tour which this movie resembled.

My only other criticism is that I would have liked to have seen her add the following important women's rights issue of self determination to the story with a trip to, let's say,  Afghanistan to showcase the life limiting abuse that women face there.

I don't really know If I've enjoyed the movie as a whole or I just enjoyed watching my beloved Julia Roberts bringing
Liz Gilbert to life . The book was really thick and full of information and I believe Ryan tried to summarize the book focusing only on the important things ( which I'm sure was not the easiest task ), so eventually  the movie looked like couple of random scenes were glued together :D . however I enjoyed the movie it has good cast and great sceneries.

I have so many issues with this film I'm almost hesitant to even write this review, since I don't really know how to start it.  I mean, what is there to say that wouldn't sound like a random checklist of insults to the film?

Maybe I should start with a synopsis.

Based on the memoirs of Elizabeth Gilbert, a young woman who abandoned her marriage and her `life as she knew it' for a lesson in self-discovery by scouring the globe in search of meaning in her life.  She went to Rome, India and Bali.  She ate, with little regard for her waistline.  She meditated with mixed results and she fell in love for the second (and longest) time.

Sadly, that is kind of all there is here.  The film doesn't dig into the meat of Liz well enough to create something more than superficial.  Even the basis for her divorce seems selfish and underdeveloped.  I understand that she and her husband were `different people' but that is the case in every relationship and Liz came across as a selfish and stubborn woman who was tired of not getting everything she wanted, despite not fully knowing what it was that she wanted.  The places she goes are beautiful and the food she eats looks scrumptious, but there is no weight added to her actions.  She seems one-note, desperate for something but not fully aware of what that something is.  And her revelations come about in a way that breathes a lot of contradiction into the film; for the message seems unevenly toned.  Her adventures lack depth and development and give the air of pointless pandering, failing to emotionally connect to the audience.  And then there are sequences and plot lines that defy all logic.  Normally one would have to suspend disbelief with cinematic musing, but a film that is adapted from a memoir needs to have a feeling of realism that `Eat Pray Love' lacks.

It makes no sense to me that Liz would be so well received instantaneously by complete strangers, but that is just me.

Julia Roberts is a good actress.  She's not great, but she's good, and she's better when she allows the natural charm of her comedic skills to take over (don't take yourself too seriously) so when she gets angry and tries to act upset she comes across awkward and unsure of herself, but when she giggles and smiles and charms the audience it works gloriously.  Thank god for Richard Jenkins and Javier Bardem, who OWN this film.  Their supporting characters are the most engaging, and their superior acting skills completely take over their scenes; especially Jenkins who breaks your heart in a million pieces while maintaining quick wit and sharp delivery.  Viola Davis is underused (I wish she had been the film's star) and James Franco is a hot mess, emphasis on `mess'.  UGH, and Billy Crudup, who is not high on my list of favorite actors, was just PERFECT here.

But really, cast aside, it was Ryan Murphy who destroyed this film.  His handling of the material was so vapid, and the poor editing choices (the flashback scenes were terribly spliced in) made the actors performances seem worse than I'm sure they were (especially Franco, who came across terribly green).

With moments of manipulated sympathies that come across more corny than sincere, `Eat Pray Love' will make you want to fast.

I've not read the wildly popular memoir so I can't compare the movie to Elizabeth Gilbert's book.

The film finds Liz, Julia Roberts, in a crisis of self. As in she doesn't know who she is -- she lives as an extension of of the man in her life and is dissatisfied. She receives a prophecy about her life and marriage. This prophecy winds its way under her skin and she festers with discontent.

What results is a slow discovery of who she is and who she wants to become. Liz removes herself from life for a year and sets out to find the happiness she hopes she can find.

This slow moving, inner journey, film will appeal to those hungry to find the "meaning of life", and to those who love introspective journeys.

OK, so the meaning of "Eat Pray Love" is to not work on your relationship (dumping your partner/spouse in the process so you can go "find yourself"), travel to Europe where fabulous people will automatically befriend you, meditate a lot but don't let go of the emotional baggage, do one nice thing for a less-fortunate, and snag yourself a hot rich guy with whom you have awesome sex. Wow, how shallow.

I simply adore this movie.  I saw it once and immediately had to buy it.  It's a favourite now and I watch it all the time.  I'd recommend this movie, especially for someone interested in Europe and travel.

Was curious about this film since it includes two of my favorite actors, James Franco and Javier Bardem. I didn't read the book prior to seeing the film. Julia Roberts was refreshing; I felt she was at ease in her acting and not trying so hard as I've often seen in her previous films.

If you've ever experienced a failed marriage and have a sense of adventure, in a modern way, you may relate well to this film.

Three men, three countries, one final positive outcome for her. (What a fairytale!)

Julia Roberts plays a soon-to-be-divorced woman fortunate enough to be able to travel long term and to the places she has chosen: Italy, India, and Bali. We see her willingness to explore her inner self, meet new people (mainly the non-threatening kind), and connect the hurt pieces of herself to the world. The best character and acting job goes to Richard Jenkins (Richard from Texas); his sincere portrayal of a man haunted by his actions hit me hard.

We see the guilt for her husband (Billy Crudup), the fling(?) with David (James Franco), and her bond to Philippe (Javier Bardem).

I could relate to all three relationships so I found the film enjoyable.

OK, I tried, I really, really tried. Lasted 18 minutes of this dreck. Try NEVER to watch a movie where Julia eats. Basically she looks like a horse trying to eat an apple through a wire fence! Her huge mouth is further enhanced by the badly done (upper) lip job that looks smeared now that she's definitely beginning to show age. I never knew what all the hulabaloo about her was about.

And this movie has been done before. It was called "Shirley Valentine", unhappy for no reason housewife abandons a perfectly good marriage/husband to run away and have an affair. Didn't work for that one, doesn't work here. She whines about going from boyfriend to boyfriend in her early life and never having time for me, me, ME!!!!!!! So what does she do? She goes overseas to go from boyfriend to boyfriend. At least that's what the other reviewers said. I ain't wasting 2 1/2 hours of MY life on this turkey!!!

If you like Julia Roberts this is a movie you should not miss, she does a great job. I enjoyed this a lot. I think that something was missing - and am not 100% sure what is was, but being fair it also appears that mant others have a similar view.

I do recommend this as it is a non-typical movie, thus; very welcome.

I was really excited to see the movie; however after the first 15 minutes I wanted to stop watching this due to it's extremely odd beginning that set the tone for the whole story.  You see in the beginning, Julia Robert's character, is a journalist who travels to Bali (Indonesia)to get a story on love.  There she meets a spiritual advisor who reads her PALM (okay this is where they started losing me)and tells her she will be married 2 times and lose most of her money within a year.  When she returns to the States she tells her husband she wants a divorce (based on that ridiculous palm reading).  Hello...can you say "selfish", "morally shallow", etc.

I forced myself to watch the whole movie thinking there had to be a lesson to be learned.  Nope.  Naddah.  The only redeeming value was the character was able to help a woman friend and her child in Bali realize their dream of owning their own home through the monetary gifts from her friends in the states.  That's the ONLY good part of the movie.

And it's ironic that in the entire movie she says she refuses to be defined by a man's love/relationship and absolutely says she will not marry again.  She ends up marrying the guy (not in the movie, but real life later on) because of his immigration status in the states...what goes around, comes around.  Did I say this movie was Shallow...yes, I did!

This has to be the most boring movie I have ever seen.  Well, I didn't actually see the whole thing, I stopped it about half way through as I couldn't stand to sit and waste anymore time watching it.  I think I would rather go to the dentist than to sit and watch this movie.

Eat Pray Love starring Julia Roberts has gotten some harsh reviews but I enjoyed this real-life story about a woman's journey to find her own path in life. Roberts performance is quite good and I like how she takes time to really learn who she is as a woman without a man defining who or what she is. Yes, she does break some hearts including her husbands and her rebound boy toy but Robert's character is trying to find her own happiness instead of depending on a man's "idea" of happiness. Along the way, she does learn to love again but first she must learn to love herself. I didn't think this film was self-indulgent or boring, check it out!
This movie may have just gone to the top of my list. It's along the lines of Under the Tuscon Sun. Yes it is a "chick" flick, but a really fun one. The scenery and acting are the best.

I read through some of the other reviews, but I absolutely loved this movie! (I love movies based on true stories.) I'm sure a great deal was missing and to really get the full picture you needed to read the book. But I would recommend this to any woman who is in her 40's (even 30's) that has experienced life and different relationships. The characters in this were truly believable. I hate to stereotype, but the "want-a-be" actor she gets mixed up with and thinks she is love with was so dead on. Her explanation / analysis in front of an audience of this kind of love was truly believable. (Think about people in your own life who have ended a realtionship and jumped right into another one without taking time to heal, etc.) I tend to be an extremely giving person and I did not look at this from the angle of her being a selfish human being. Why? Well a two hour movie is not going to give you the complete picture without reading the book.

The movie doesn't really develop her relationship gone sour with her husband and I would hope the book explained / had more detail on this. I wasn't making an assumption this non christian suddendly decides as her last resort sto pray to God (it was very apparent she lacked this in her life) for help and then tell her husband it's over. There is always alot more to a story. My guage was that the movie picked up pretty much at the end of a relationship and that the main character was not willing to work on it. Once again we are missing the "rest of the story". So you have to pick up her journey from there.

Talk about courage. Imagine, as she stated in the movie, she has always been in a realtionship with someone since 15 and now she is not in any relationship and completely leaving her comfort zone. She's not moving to another state - she is leaving the country!! Everyone she knows, everyday surroundings, all of it! Think about taking that kind of a risk in todays world as a single female. And along this journey they portrayed that she met some truly good people Vs. those trying to harm. Talk about luck and finding goodness in others. Once again the movie portrays the more sunshine piece of this and not the difficult / pissy situations she encountered by going to 3 different places she was not familiar with. Imagine having a great time in Italy, being happy and then uprooting yourself to India with no guarantees of any sort. (If you want to analzye it here is this needy person who was looking for anyone to fulfill what was missing from her life and now she is on a quest to find peace within herself that doesn't necessarily equate to being with someone. Here was a dependent person who now is independent. That is a leap).

This movie conveyed a sense of real people with real emotions. I cried when the character from Texas finally opened up to her and explained why he needed to forgive himself. And I have no doubt that he truly gave her the nickname "Groceries". It was brilliant when her ex-husband to be conveyed to her that he had no idea what her issues were. Pathetic yes from the standpoint that people fail to truly communicate with each other in life. The characters in this were believable. Even the Brazilian gentleman she meets. I would bet  it was true that this guy was hurt so badly by his ex-wife that he hadn't given his heart to anyone in almost 10 years.

Sure based on some of the reviews not everyone will like this movie. But it you have taken chances in life and moved from your comfort zone you may have a totally different reaction to this movie and a different level of interpretation. In closing another interpretation - I was so very disappointed years ago when I finally watched "The Way We Were" with Barbara Streistand. I did not think it was a love story at all. I saw this woman who continually gave to someone and so desperately wanted their love and they would never love her the same. When it was over I couldn't believe this movie was ever hyped as a love story. Maybe one sided. Food for thought -  when you read reviews please remember everyone has their own opinions / interpretations based on their own life experiences. Read more than one review before you make a decision.

When this movie was over I was reminded of how grateful I am for what I have in my life and the good people I have met along the way. And how fortunate I was that I had found true love.

You guessed it, not my turn to pick the movie. In the past this worked for the best, getting exposed to good movies I would not had picked otherwise. This time though I was itching for a magazine well before the movie was halfway through.

A woman in mid-life crisis ends her unfulfilling marriage to her equally immature and directionless husband for no other major reason. The divorce is messy with a lot of guilt to be distributed around. A brief (cougar-)affair ends equally badly so she embarks in a year-long journey to redefine herself.

The journey starts from Italy where apparently she learns to appreciate life's little pleasures and how to enjoy them guilt-free. This part made me hungry for good Italian pasta with fresh tomato sauce and basil but little else. Having said that I have been to Naples and (with all due respect to my Napolitano friends), one can find much better-tasting pizza in New York.
By the way, when someone decides to accept her body no matter its imperfections and goes shopping for larger jeans, she does not then proceed to force the zippers of ...smaller sizes.

India was next and it was a disaster. The guru she has traveled so far to meet is visiting the US and her disciples run her ashram like something between a hostel and a Scientology sweat-shop. She receives no enlightening guidance except some overused bromides from a Texan in his post-alcoholic guilt trip.
I love Indian culture and have a great respect for Indian people. However, unlike SLUMDOG MILLIONAIRE, this movie will not make you want to visit this mesmerizing country.

Finally, Bali where she meets again a toothless old medicine-man/palm reader. She copies some notes; she runs a short but effective charity fund; and she finds lust/love in the sad eyes of a Brazilian divorcee. What did she learn in the previous year: apparently nothing because she is about to run away from that relationship as well. Will she? Well, at that point point I could not care less.

I gave it 2-stars solely for the travelogue images.

Oh please - what were they thinking?? Another little rich girl gets sympathy for not having everything she wants in life, and applauded for focusing solely on herself. Jumping from one man to another to fill her own emptiness - oh poor baby. If she could travel where she wanted, and eat what she wanted, and enjoy her money, that's fine; but to actually write a book and have a film about your boring self is another thing.

No worries about job, money, responsibilities or obligations to others - no wonder she experienced ennui. Now she's even wealthier for publishing the nauseating drivel about her useless life, and we're expected to think of her as courageous and deep. No way.

Oh, she leaves the men, but she's the one who's "heartbroken"??? I'm not saying she should have stayed with them if she didn't want to, but the entire story is so ridiculous.

didn't think I would, but I did like this movie. I tend not to care too much for melodramatic movies about the rich and their little problems, but...

If you aren't sick of movies about very wealthy people having spiritual crises and going off to find themselves (and extremely handsome lovers), it's worth a watch.
This movie is not worth the time it would take to write a review. Garbage. At least Julia made some $$$$ (not mine thank you JESUS).

I loved  the book but the movie was a disappointment. If I would have seen the movie first I would not have read the book. I am a Julia Roberts fan but she wasn't the right lead for the movie maybe because she was a distraction and I couldn't not see "Julia Roberts"
It;s a chick flick for sure. I had seen it in the movie theater, and wanted my own copy. I truly enjoyed it. Beautiful scenery.

I have tried reading Eat, Pray, Love and could not finish it.  While I am sure that it is difficult making a radical change so late in life, I still found the author's story dull.  I was looking forward to the movie and perhaps would be able to get a different opinion on the matter.

That being said, this movie was worse than the book.  The highlight for me was being able to see gorgeous parts of Italy, but it was a complete struggle not to leave the theatre before the movie ended.

It's very difficult to translate a book into a movie and this one failed.  The movie felt like it went on forever and it didn't connect with the audience.  It was difficult for me to sympathize or even like the Liz character.  The movie is boring, yet it also felt rushed.  If they were trying to convey Liz's struggles and her journey to self-discovery, it was done poorly.  It's difficult to understand how the character could learn anything when we don't really get a chance to connect with her since the movie just speeds through the entire process, while managing to bore the audience.

A big BOO to this movie.

As an Australian,I must say that this film exemplifies some of the worst characteristics a hollywood studio wants the rest of the world to think about American women.
Shallow,narcissitic,selfish,mired in'comfort',regarding poverty as 'picturesque'[and avoiding it like the plague in India and Bali except for one sight of the ride from the airport in the case of the latter].
I wouldn't be suprised if Al Quaeda used it as part of their recruiting drivel.
It really is awful and while my wife and I watched it in elequent surprise,I reflected on the beautiful shots of the luxury ashram in India and resort in Bali, thinking of the thousands of unsung people in the world who actually do good for other people,the thousands who travel to really meet 'ordinary' people and try to help their environments.
Such a morally twisted work as this does very poor service to the view of the American middle class.
Perhaps big American studio bosses should leave deep and serious thinking to the British.
Very few of them seem capable of it.
This is why the  best American film of the last ten years remains Scorseses' 'Aviator' .A wonderful film.

I watched movie first with a friend while on vacation, I then read the book and loved both. Have since read Committed (also by Gilbert) and enjoyed all. I now look forward to watching the movie of Eat Pray Love again (Julia Roberts did an excellent job, as I expected).

Easy film to watch.  Fun section in Italy.  India-clever themes.
Bali-love interest.  Good to watch as a review before her next book.

`Eat, Pray, Love' is an average film with a decent message and as I haven't read the book I can only review this film based on it's own merits, rather than comparing it to the message the book imparts.

This film follows Liz (Julia Roberts) after she divorces her husband and travels to Italy, India and Bali as she tries to find some meaning in her life.  She learns about herself, makes some friends and has some amazing experiences, like travel will often do for anyone.

I hate to say it, but this film is overly sentimental and whilst the basic message is a good one (being true to yourself and finding god within you) this film feels like it has to spell it out for you as if you are stupid and can't grasp the message being rammed down your throat at every turn.  This may sound harsh and I don't mean it to, as this is perfectly watchable and entertaining, but I don't know why film makers feel the need to dumb things down to such a degree that they almost insult the viewers intelligence.  The `meaningful' voice-overs spelling things out particularly started to grate by the end of the film.

Roberts is pretty average in this film and Bardem is probably the best of the actors here.  Saying that, Richard Jenkins is very good as well and deserves a mention.  The direction is ok and is certainly very glossy and shows the countries off to spectacular effect (like a glorified tourist advert for each destination), but it lacks a certain depth and, like the film in general, it feels rather superficial.

Don't get me wrong, this film is good enough and certainly has something to offer, but it has no nuance and isn't as `deep' as it likes to think it is.  The book may be a whole lot better, but judging this is on it's own merits I'd say this is a good but not great film and it is worth a watch; just don't expect too much and you should be fine.

Feel free to check out my blog which can be found on my profile page.

This movie misses the mark in every way.  It never becomes clear what demons Gilbert is wrestling with, she doesn't seem to really learn anything from her travels, and the big questions of life are barely even hinted at, much less seriously engaged.  Having sugary Julia Roberts play Gilbert only makes all of this worse. And to top it off, the movie is drainingly boring, with even the scenery failing to generate interest.  In short, the movie lacks both substance *and* style.

I hope the book is better than the movie.  More importantly, I hope the real Elizabeth Gilbert has more depth than the shallow character presented to us.

Not recommended, not even to waste time ... on second thought, maybe this movie would work well as a sleep aid.
MOVIE WAS AWESOME AND HAD A LOT OF MEANING.  HAD ALREADY SEEN IT AND IT WAS A MUST HAVE.  THE SECOND DVD WAS FOR A FRIEND OF MINE.

Waste of time, I knew I did not want to see this movie and I am glad I waited for the video so at least I did not waste my $$ too.
Never had the desire to read this book, I think the Author is selfish and needs to get over her self. I hope her ex found a better women to be with one who doesn't leave because she is hungry for pasta!!

Boring movie, really disappointed.

Eat Pray Love [Blu-ray] This was a DVD that we purchased at a very reasonable price and really got more than we expected. It was brand new and the quality of the picture was superb. The purchase process with Amazon was smooth as always.
This is becoming one of my all-time favorite books!  I loved the movie, but as has been said, "the book is always better."

Is there a more wishy washy actress than Julia Roberts? I certainly haven't come across one. Perhaps the least deserving Best Actress Oscar winner in history, Roberts has relied on her 'charming smile' to get through roles without any discernible 'acting' going on. Case in point : "Erin Brokovich" and the woefully overwrought "My Best Friends Wedding". However, there are some of us who find Roberts' wide jawed smile rather disconcerting, unsettling and a little frightening, and lets just say this film does nothing to prove her case as an 'actress'.

The book was bad enough (not many of you know that what happened to the author after the book was published and it is probably not going to make a very savory movie), but the film takes all of its vapid elements and multiplies it by a 100. The 'Pray' section for instance, is bewildering. Its difficult to ascertain what Roberts is going through when she closes her eyes on her meditative journeys, but on film these segments don't make any sense and don't reveal anything at all, except that a woman somewhere is closing her eyes. The director is especially gifted at sucking the life out of a scene, it has to be mentioned.

The problem is with the script, as well as with Roberts over-confident performance. She might perhaps think that shes at a stage in her life where she can 'walk through' any role, but lets face it, the woman barely got through "The Mexican" without being upstaged by Pitt at every stage so she should really rethink her acting strategies. The worst part is the end, which neatly ties together her escapades and presents it as a more holistic episode of "Sex and the City" (should be seen to be believed). The supporting cast, often goodlooking but seldom talented, are totally wasted. The cinematography is beautiful but any of you with a home camera in any of these locations would find it hard to take a bad shot, so thats not saying much. Bali and Italy are pretty hard to tamper with on film. Sadly, they seemed to have captured the worst of India here, which is stereotypical of a film that tries to go the spiritual route (much like Kate Winslet in "Holy Smoke"). Javier Bardem, who is one of the worlds most nuanced actors is relegated to the role of a caricature here, while James Franco (whos lets face it is not going to win an Oscar for expressionism) plays an enlightened palm reader in Bali, which doesn't at all help matters. Billy Crudup is the best thing about this film, and at least he has the decency to only appear for a few minutes here and there.

Bottom line, if you don't like Roberts' 'work', stay far, far away. Also, it might be of note that was a lot of eating going on in the film, and much less praying and loving. Well, at least they could keep their lunch down. Grab a pillow and pray for daylight if this is the mess you plan on renting tonight.

An abominable film with no redeeming qualities.

Two stars. Both out of generosity.

I'm one of those people who actually really liked this book.  Well, to say it better - I really enjoyed "eating" and "loving" - the "praying" was a little lost on me and seemed a little lengthy in comparison.  I finally got around to watching the movie this past weekend.  I liked it.  It wasn't my favorite movie..... but I thought it was decent.  I do think the book is a LOT better.  It's just too large a subject matter to try to cram into a 2 hour long movie.

Julie Roberts was the ideal choice for the main character, Liz.  I thought she brought a lot to the character - after all, this story is based on a real woman's life experiences.  At times, the movie seemed a bit rushed, but again, I think that has more to do with the fact that you're cramming a year long journey into 2 hours of film.

A lot of people didn't like the book, and subsequently the movie, because they felt that it was all me, me, me and that the author was self-centered or self-righteous.  Newsflash - the book is a memoir - which is autobiographical writing.  Did those people not realize that?

I personally enjoyed the movie - but then again, I really enjoyed the book.  A friend of mine hated the book, but liked the movie - go figure!  It's hard for me to judge because I actually have read the book, but I think I was able to get more out of the movie because I knew a little bit more about what was actually happening - the parts of the story that the movie only touched on or didn't include at all.  My only real disappointment was that the Florence + the Machine song wasn't even in the movie - only the trailer!

I have ordered from Amazon for many years and this company has the best service I have ever recieved. My DVD arrived quickly and was just like new. I am very pleased.
Eat, Pray,Love has become one of my favorite movies and I am happy to add it to my video library.
I loved this movie in the theater; I couldn't wait for this to come to DVD and I can't stop watching it!

Seller promptly sent the item.  The item was in excellent condition.  I would use this seller again.  Great movie!!!!  I have watched it several times.  The book is as good as the movie.  A wonderful romance movie.

It amazes me that the ones out number any of the other start ratings for this movie or film. I wonder how many of those people who love to leave "their" revies even read the book prior to viewing the movie. It has two of the most wonderful actors still in the twenty first centry. There is a great story that is told and in it being told you go on a journey that takes you to countries you may never get to visit. It if you watch and really listen can lift your spirit and soul. This person who states we are our own "God" could not be more "WRONG" than he or she and thier negative review states. I am married, sharing my life on Valentines day 15yrs with the same person. We have five or with the lil doggies seveon children that we watched the film with. Ages ranging from one to 28. Each of their thoughts of the film were similar to our but they would have rated the film a 3.5 stars. This film though Julia who seeks her Soul & Spirit to be shined upon, would relate to any Male, Female or in between. Honestly rent it prior to buying it. This way you save a little and if then you choose to buy it great. If you still did enjoy it but not enough to add to your collection, at least you can leave a review to help other's attempt to make a move on renting or buying the film. Oh and please those 56 one ratings each used the word Cubin actor, come on that in itself tells you a little something about what their ratings worth holds. Cheers, Peace & Blessings. Please know that though I did not agree with those I speak of in no way do I take away from their right to speak freely. I do however stand on what I said to the "one" person who said we are our own "God". That holds no value what so ever. That I do stand by. We may all see or worship "God" or our higher power differently but when all is said and done it equals out to be the same "higher power". Which is not we ourselves.

Julia Roberts is a great actress and a beautiful woman. In this movie she acted well and was beautiful but the movie as a whole was not that good. The movie lacked depth and a compelling storyline. It was not entertaining and overly boring and drawn out. On a positive note it was visually stunning at times and the camera work in Bali was outstanding.

i was really surprised with the great quality of the video and its box. I was expecting scratches on the dvd and a damaged box, so i was really happy to find i was wrong in this case. I will probably buy from this seller again.
Sweet, warm, colorful, great music. Makes you want to travel !!!  I only have 3 stamps on my passport and now it's m.i.a. Traveling opens your heart!!  Love the affectionate nature of the film.

There is a reason why this movie costs so little to "rent" on Amazon.com in comparison to the rest of the videos that came out around the same time. I wanted to like it but I have to echo what the other reviews said about it. It was almost impossible to empathize with anything this woman was feeling, hard to relate to anything in this story. This story should have been titled "How much I love myself". The main character is self absorbed, irrational and unreasonable. She wanders far and wide to find herself and "marvel" at something, and throws away everything she has ever worked for and hurts people that did not deserve to be hurt. An important message in this movie was that in order to change how you feel you must change how you think. and yes it is very difficult. You do not have to take a trip around the world to teach yourself to love honestly, to be true to yourself or to find spirituality. I would suggest this movie if you have two hours that you really want to waste. If you have read the book (I havent), you may want to watch it. If you're looking for a movie with a deeper message then don't waste your time or money.

In short pass. I watched this drivel with my mother over the holidays thinking it would be a wonderful chic flick with beautiful travel cinematography. It was terribly boring, no great travel shots and a waste of our time. Neither my mother nor myself are fans of Julia Roberts but thought perhaps this movie might be fine because of the travel. I only paid $1 from the kiosk rental but still not worth it. Save your money and time - even if on sale. I agree with another reviewer the companions in Italy were the most interesting part of the movie but never really developed the characters. The reason for the main character's up and leaving husband - the hopping in/out of bed from husband to flaky actor to sensual Javier Bardem. I could not emphathize with the character. Too self absorbed and she brought the unhappiness upon herself. For a similar chic flick I'd rather watch Under the Tuscan Sun which had a nice ensemble of characters that were allowed to develop; not Eat Pray Love.

This movie was one of the most long, drawn out, boring films I have every seen.  2 1/2 hours of my life wasted.  The only reason I hung in there was because of Julia Roberts starring role.  Not one of her better endeavors.  Don't waste your time.

I'll admit: I can't give a Short Attention Span Summary because I couldn't make it through the whole film. Who knew that a single woman finding herself while backpacking could fill up so much space or make such an intensely boring movie?

Save your money.
THE BOOK IS BETTER BUT THIS MOVIE WILL NOT DISAPPOINT.  IT'S ONE TO WATCH EVERY YEAR OR SO AND THE SCENERY IS BEAUTIFUL. . . LOOKED MAGNIFICANT ON THE MOVIE SCREEN IN THE THEATER.

I have watched this movie numerous times and now am embarking on the journey through the novel. Yesterday as I sat through a snowstorm, I traveled around the world through the movie not once, but twice, as my eyes grew weary from reading the novel. I would give this movie 4 thumbs up if I had the capabilities!

I am a huge fan of Julia Roberts and don't mind what people label as chick flicks about self discovery such as "Under the Tuscan Sun", but this film is so tedious and self indulgent that I had to watch it over two nights.  When I looked at the packaging it was mis-printed and said the running time was 4hours and 46 minutes and it really did feel that long.  To be fair, the first portion of the film that took place in Italy was okay, but the rest of it was dull as dirt.  I am sure there are those who really enjoyed it, but I was not one. Sorry!

I was hoping the movie would be more entertaining than the book.  This movie is equally as horrible as the book.  If you're curious about the film, I would save your money and check it out from your local library.

The main character is shallow and self-absorbed.  The acting is horrible.  In this film, Julia Roberts has only two expressions, the blank stare and the blank stare with a cheesy smile.

You'll love the scenery in this movie - especially of course ROME with Bali second. I think there was great effort by the director to make you feel like you're there too.

It doesn't matter that I read the book. This movie leaves far too much of the relationships to the imagination. Especially the two most important relationships of the main character, Liz. First we discover that Liz is unhappy in her marriage, but we're not exactly sure why. The dialogue makes an effort to try to fill us in... but we've arrived at the very end of the marriage and aren't privy to the WHY.

What kinda bothers me about the character, Liz, is that she jumps right into another relationship while going through her divorce, but this time we see it through from beginning to end and STILL aren't privy to the "fights" they later discuss when breaking up.

Do not read further if you don't want the story ruined...

Liz's next relationship evolves the same way ... but there's no chemistry that I can see - although they seem to pretend there is - here it really seems like acting. The Brazilian boyfriend seems too course for her... he seems just WRONG... that's not to say I haven't seen this actor in other movies and thought he was fantastic... it's just that with Julia Roberts it doesn't work. But apparently as the movie ends, he's "the one". After less than a year in which she broke up her marriage, ended her interim relationship, she has found Mr. IT? It's too fairy tale for me... but this is supposedly based on a true story so I guess it's possible. I've been married and divorced... it's not often that people rebound so quickly. That amazes me... it's just not my own experience. For me this movie left me cold... I didn't feel this woman had truly progressed emotionally... she just jumped from partner to partner. And I felt the same way reading the book.

Thought there would me more fluff and not so much real things people go through in life. Although the star does it with not much thought to how things get paid for, it still stuck deep into what each of us is searching for. The meaning we each give to the world is determined by each of us. I watched the movie 3 times in a row,,,,,,, and I am not even a fan of Julia. I bet the book is great.but watch the DVD, and you get the point.

I will start off by saying that I hated the book.  Hated it!  So, why did I watch the movie?  Good question.  I had hoped it would be better than the book.  Still selfish.  Still boring.

You will love this book if:  you are in an unfulfilling marriage and hate your partner; feel like you should be doing something "better" with your life; just are not a happy person...

If you love your husband and life, you cannot relate to this selfish person.  Even Julia Roberts could not make her likeable.

The movie had the feel of a New York Times Magazine article put to film.  Ugh.  Self-involved, self-indulgent, East Coast, upper-middle class, spoiled  woman (who supposedly loses "all her money" at the beginning of the film but still can fly to Rome, hang out for months at a time with no visible means of support, then hang out in India for another few months, then Bali for a few months after that -- who knew you losing all your money resulted in a jet-set lifestyle?) travels the world to find herself and in the end, doesn't really do a very good job at that simple task.  This is just a variation of the annoying paeans to the bourgeoisie we see every couple of years, e.g., "Click!"; "The Family Man."  If you want real self-discovery material, see "The Razor's Edge" or the unfortunately forgotten "Bagdad Caf."

As for Ms. Roberts, she seems bent on fulfilling her own prophecy from "Notting Hill": "one day not long from now, my looks will go, they will discover I can't act and I will become some sad middle-aged woman who looks a bit like someone who was famous for a while."

The way they hyped up this movie and book - whose premise I really do like - I expected a nice piece depicting someone's journey through self-discovery. Instead, it turned out to be a trite two hour movie depicting the shameless self-indulgences and superficiality of a vain person on the quest for the elusive "finding yourself" mantra she undoubtedly read up upon in the self help aisle at Barnes and Noble. Because of how the character acted and was portrayed, the audience just never gets to identify and empathize with her and her "problems". For two hours you sit there and watch her whine about her life, how it is/was so unhappy and unfulfilled and what have you, but you never know why really. If the goal is to have the audience empathize with a character and identify with it, they have to know what's bothering them, be let in on their pain and unhappiness. That is what makes a great movie. The writers in this one seemed to want the audience to just take their word for it that she was unhappy and unfulfilled - despite all evidence to the contrary. Someone once said if the problem is in one's head, it still is a problem. But in this movie, we never get to see what that is - imagined or real. The worst thing a movie maker can do is create unrelateable characters.

Julia Roberts did a lousy job and her character is both unlikeable and unrelateable. This movie is supposed to tell us that material things and money are not the source to happiness and that there are other sources of happiness unrelated to such external things. Yet the main character (Roberts) spends a year travelling around the world living in great places that cost a lot of money. Later on, this movie promoted a lip-gloss by Lnacome or something. Yeah...way to send a message about material things not mattering. They should have pointed out that trying to find yourself when you are broke is much harder to do. Luckily, Roberts in this movie didn't have to worry about that "tiny detail". One should be so lucky to have so much money that it is not worth mentioning anymore - even though it still is used to buy you all the sanity and self-discovery trips in the world.

But it is not just that. The main character was annoying for other reasons as well. I mean her spiritual guide is a self-announced medicine man in Bali with amnesia. Yes amnesia, as in brain damage. She turns her life upside down because of the random crap he made up and told her, and then a year later when she goes back, to tell her "mentor" what she did, he doesnt even remember her!! It was hilarious. I thought they were kidding and that at this point the movie would take a turn; that her character would finally realize how immature and insane it was to do all those things to herself based on the random musings of a silly, old man who doesnt even know her. But NO. It stayed. That was it. Oh so conveniently, the shaman starts suddenly remembering her after she is about to burst into tears at the realization that she might have screwed up her life based on the words of a random, senile man.  That's deep.

The movie went downhill from there at an alarming rate. I have never seen so much substance-deficiency and implausibility of both story and characters packed into two hours or so of narcissistic screen time for a middle-aged actress. The supporting characters were unlikable too and Julia Roberts just seemed too old and burned out for some of the "boys" she dated - like James Franco. They wanted to make it look like her relationship with Franco - which she started 5 minutes after her divorce by the way - didn't work out for other deep reasons, like she loved him, but it is obvious that it didn't work out cause she is too old for him and he a vacuous moron.  And then Javier Bardem. Obviously both of these people are on rebound, especially Bardem (who is 39 and has a 20 year old son but ok) but still after a couple of weeks of humping in the tropical hut, he confesses his ever endearing love for her like a starry-eyed 17 year old teenager. I seriously thought she knew better and would respond that she didn't feel the same way, that she didn't love him. But ta da, it turns out - despite all evidence to the contrary and what we see - she is in fact madly in love with him but (how original) is too scared to admit it cause she is afraid to get hurt. Yeah right. Could they have packed any more lame cliches into that?

They could and they did because in the end, just like any other woman I guess, all she needed obviously to get out of her funk was love and riding off into the sunset (literally) with her man.

Coming out of this garbage they tried to pass as a "wonderful journey" I figured that not only did I not get anything out of this movie and the supposed journey, but that obviously neither did the protagonist. Just as we never found out why she was really having a crisis and was unhappy, we also never find out why and how she got happy again. This movie is based on the premise that she lost her mojo and needed to find it, but looking closer it seems that she never had it. After that one year of travelling and exploring and meeting all these supposedly cool and enlightened people (quitters is more like it, see Bardem's character), she doesnt seem to have found more purpose in life than before. She doesnt look and act changed, enlightened or as if she had gained some insight into who she really is and what she really wants out of life. She spent a year travelling around, "hanging out" and having a good time and all she got to show for is a man. As expected, because by being a self-absorbed, spoiled brat who never had to do a hard day's work in life and doesn't listen to people you are not likely to gain insight into anything. Spiritually, she could have been Carrie Bradshaw's sidekick when she went into hysteria.

In the end, she is exactly where she started: nowhere, drowning in her own superficiality and shallow-ness. The only exciting thing in her life will be a long distance relationship with Bardem between Bali and New York until she gets bored again and leaves, thinking that maybe the answers in life are to be found in the elusive wisdom of this one medicine man she read up upon on her last trip to the self help aisle - this time at Borders.
I expected more. But it is nice to watch and see some of  the settings in Europe.  Nice

Julia Robert's character has no brain! That is the first thing that comes to mind, the story doesn't go into detail to explain to the audience why she is so unhappy as we the audience CANNOT find reason for her to BE UNHAPPY. Next ..it seemed as if she coudln't decide anything for herself, people were telling her what to do, what to feel..and its like she couldn't decide where or what to think or do...don't waste your time..the only thing nice about this crazy movie is that the scenery is beautiful but the character comes off as an unthankful woman who really doesn't have reason to jump around continents!

Ok, so the "character" of Elizabeth is shallow, entitled, etc....I read the book, before it became a "sensation", or before i was aware of it becoming a sensation. I think that is probably b/c there are probably thousands of woman out there who have felt what she is feeling yet don't have the cash or profession to take off for a year.  While the lead up to why Elizabeth is so unhappy in her marriage is barely hinted at in the movie (this i agree with, except it's only a two hour movie, and it would take at least 1/2 hour or 40 minutes to adequately portray that, and we, the audience, want to see Italy, so, chop chop), it is covered quite painfully actually in the book, at which point i almost put it down. I think the reason i didn't put the book down, was because Gilbert can actually be quite a good writer. There are soooo many self-help/travelogue/transformative whatever books out there, which i might be inclined to read, and have tried, and after a few dozen or so over the years, most discarded after a chapter or two, the narrator here is self aware enough to point out her own flaws and write well while doing it, so i didn't put it down. If you read any interviews with E. Gilbert, or the first couple of chapters of her other book Committed, you might come away understanding that she really didn't intend or expect this to become a sensation. I have been known on principle, not to see something or read something, b/c it is  a sensation, makes me distrust it. Whatever, I went to see the movie to get a vicarious trip to Bali and Italy, which i got, so I'm not complaining too much. And the whole complaint that these are first world problems and thus shallow, etc., yes, except if you are THAT unhappy in a marriage, get out before you inflict yourselves on children. Not everyone grew up with a perfect example of how to have a happy marriage, and it isn't always their fault for not having that example. This movie is admittedly the hollywood version of one woman's "journey".

I am not a woman writing this and I did not read the novel.

On the other hand I am sucker of films that make me travel.  This film satisfied me largely in this aspect.

Beautifully shot, with a soundtrack that is "sans faute".

The film does not portray Liz as an idiotic waif who throws herself head on into the place wherever she goes.

She appears to be detached from the situations involved.

In the Indian ashram, she readily accepts with a large smile to do PR job, foregoing meditation.

The scenes with the chaman in Bali is downright funny.  The chaman's delivery of philoshopy is countered by humorous comments by his assistant which seems to confirm the mild charlatan aspect.

The films does not take itself too seriously, despite the underlying heavy "searching for a sense in life" theme.
THIS MOVIE IS FOR ALL THOSE NORTHAMERICAN WOMEN IN THEIR MIDDLE AGE CRISIS!! GOT DIVORCE AND FIND THE NEXT GUY.SOUNDS NEW? NOPE...
Movie arrived as advertised, good price and fast shipping. The movie is very good. Have to watch it all and think about the name of it, then it makes more sense.
I enjoyed this movie, that is why I purchased it through Amazon. Delivery was fast , first one came damaged .Replacement came quickly and was fine.
Wanted this for a Christmas gift and our local stores were out of stock. Made it just in time despite bad weather. Thanks Amazon!

This movie awakens your inner thoughts. Where am I going,what is important, who am I. It is fun to watch and the scenes are beautiful. Life is short live it to it's fullest.
Enjoyed every minute of the movie.

Let me start out by saying that I did read the book before seeing the movie, and well...that was no easy task. Once I got passed the part where Liz is in Italy, I had to force myself to get through the remaining two-thirds of the book. I never saw the movie in theaters, because I knew I wanted to finish the book before watching the film, but it took me several months to finally get through the book. Once I finished my reading, I was verrrry disappointed and was hoping that the film, which had just come out on DVD/BluRay, would bring this woman's story to life and prove much less painful to sit through as it was to read.

Often, books are made into films that really shouldn't be. Generally, people tend to prefer the book over the movie, but at least the film is "pretty good" and watchable. Not the case with Eat, Pray, Love! I think the main issue is that it isn't another great fiction novel about love, or wizards, or vampires. Basically, the book reads like a diary or journal. This isn't a "story" or a "tale" it is simply the author, Elizabeth Gilbert's, account of everything that happened to her during this period of her life. So there is honestly no beginning, middle, and end. There is no climax, not even a plot. This kind of writing can slide in the literary world (referred to as non-fiction or autobiography) but it's very difficult to translate non-fiction to the big screen unless it's a documentary, like March of the Penguins or something.

I don't know what I was expecting from the film... I guess I thought maybe the filmmakers would add in a plot to make it more interesting. Honestly, the movie probably wouldn't have been too bad if it were simply BASED on the book, not translated verbatim. But no, the movie was filmed the way the book was written, minus all the narrative that made the book at least sometimes amusing or intriguing. It is IMPOSSIBLE to sympathize with the character in the film... basically it just appears that Liz is suddenly very unhappy in her marriage for some reason, and instead of discussing it with her husband like an adult or putting forth any effort at all to save the marriage, she bolts. BAM! DIVORCE! Makes you want to grab her by the face and say "look you dumb bitch, this isn't some casual boyfriend who you don't really like anymore, so you just break it off and move on. He is your HUSBAND!" What kind of a message is this woman sending out? That if you are even the slightest bit unhappy in your marriage, you don't address the problem, you just file for divorce and run away to a different country??

So the film starts out with the main character, Liz, pulling a very selfish move (and practically out of nowhere since the movie lacks the narrative that the book includes to provide a bit of explanation and reason for her actions..), making her rather unlikeable and unable to relate to. A main character that the audience hates... not a good way to start off a motion picture. The part in Italy was at least visually appealing (and appetizing..), however, kind of randomly pieced together like a collage, including various shots of tourist spots, food, Italian people, and Julia Roberts doing the "Julia Roberts laugh." I recall the scene where she claims to have gained all this weight and is struggling (to the point of having to lie on the floor) to put on a pair of jeans, even though there is no visual evidence of this supposed "weight gain." It's like when a 110 lb woman is complaining about her love handles... you just kind of want to slap her.

I was watching the movie with a friend who hadn't even read the book, so I couldn't even imagine how torturous this movie-watching experience was for her. Once it got to the VERY sudden flip flop over to Bali, my friend and I just couldn't take it anymore and fast-fowarded to the rather anti-climactic love scene with Javier Bardem. I remembered seeing him in the previews and wondered which character he was going to portray in the film, but was surprised to see him playing a character who, in the book, was supposed to be much older than Liz. I'm pretty certain that Javier Bardem is younger than, or at least the same age as Julia Roberts, but whatever. Soon after this scene, they run away together and the movie concludes with them riding a boat off into the distance or something cliche like that.

Bottom line: This movie has no plot, the main character is irritating and impossible to relate to, and the last two-thirds of the movie (and the book) are extremely difficult to get through without burying your face into a pillow and screaming. The only delightful part of the film is Richard Jenkins' portrayal of the character Richard from Texas, but sadly his appearance in the film ends very abruptly and the movie starts to suck again. And the brief period in which she dates David, played by james Franco, seems pointless, unnecessary and almost kind of irrelevant to the rest of the film. Unless you're in the mood to watch a crappy movie and make fun of it with a friend or loved one, I suggest not wasting your time or money on this one.

I'm a big fan of Julia Roberts and James Franco and am truly surprised that either of them would attach themselves to this schlock. The main character Liz is a self absorbed bitch. I kept thinking it has to get better. The ending is going to be great. But as predictable as any chick flick, she falls for "the guy" like that's the only salvation available. So much for finding yourself. It's an awful movie. And as it seems that's a common opinion. I only wish I would have asked more people before I wasted the 2+ hours.
Not a good or bad movie. I found it a little drawn out. It could have been made a lot shorter and would have been better.
My wife wanted to get this one "Eat, Pray, Love". I thought it was going to be another mushy chick flick, which it kind of was but it was a really good story, I thoroughly enjoyed this movie!!

If you are a Julia Roberts fan, then this movie is a must see.
If not, then the storyline and the performances, especially Julia, will have you loving the movie.
Well worth a watch.

I have never reviewed a movie.  This movie was so terrible, however, I thought I should warn you before you committed yourself to watch it with others.  Don't make this mistake!

The book has to be better than the movie!  The movie is a waste of time.  I felt no compassion for Julia Robert's character. Her big crises in life?  Not loving a devoted husband.  "Losing herself" in relationships as evidenced by the remodeling of her kitchen when she is not a cook.  Not being able to clear her mind during meditation.  Jumping from man to man to make herself feel better, and hurting these men in the process.

Her big contributions in life?  Praying for a 17-year old who does not want to be the bride in an arranged marriage.  Asking her friends to use the money they would spend on her birthday presents to help her friend in Bali buy a house.

If you want to see a self-indulgent, rich girl, cope with the "crises" she has created in life, then you may enjoy this movie.  Most of us, however, have pains much harder than this woman, and we have to pick ourselves up each day, go to work, and care for our loved ones.  It is hard to feel for a woman who has no real problems - save her selfishness - and then has the time and money to travel the world and make herself feel better.
Dull, uninspired, selfish, and lacking charisma.  Julia is a great actress and the scenery where she travels is absolutely beautiful, but the pace and characters were boring.
I loved this movie!  It brought the viewer through so many emotions we women of a certain age go through.  Now only if we all could make the life choice to live our dreams.

Love all of Julia Roberts movies but this one was on the bottom of my list. It was just too all over the place. Wasn't sure if she should eat more pray more or fall in love more.
Not one of her better movies.

I knew the moment I heard Julie Roberts was cast as the lead in Eat, Pray, Love! the movie was doomed. Now don't get me wrong, I've been a long time fan of Julie Roberts since the early days, and thoroughly enjoyed Pretty Woman, Erin Brockovich, Notting Hill, and Charlie Wilson's War.  What's happened to her acting talents since then is a mystery.  Roberts acting range these days seems to be limited to either a fast talking loud mouth adolescent or an emotionally collapsed, poor me, lost soul wandering through life.  I think directors, producers, and writers get blindsided by all of the hype around a star. From my point of view, Julia Roberts amazing lack of depth in this role is responsible for the failure of the film. Even Javier Bardem couldn't save it.  Julia's song I fear, has been sung.

Eat, Pray, Love's heroine should have been a younger, more earthy woman who could bring to life the emotional trauma in her marriage, her lusty full bodied eating adventures in Italy, and finally some reasonable realistic interpretation of having found some serenity and peace through self-exploration and the mysteries of meditation.  They should have held auditions before committing.(Perhaps Rachel McAdams in The Notebook - an Oscar performance if I ever saw one).

Ryan Murphy is a talented writer and director who produced the racy Nip/Tuck, and the now highly popular Glee.  We know he's talented so what happened with Eat, Pray, Love? Did he allow Roberts to interpret the role for him?  Sure looks that way, as his
characters on Nip/Tuck were complex. At least Viola Davis was in it, and she brings a depth to any role you see her in. The film for all its beauty in parts was as shallow as Roberts acting.  What a shame!  So many of us who read the book were looking forward to a great fun movie and in the end it was disposable.
Viola Davis - A+ - Javier Bardem - A - Richard Jenkins - A -
Julia Roberts - D.

I've missed Julia Roberts.  Either I have been watching different movies or she hasn't been in many lately. I forgot how much I enjoyed her acting.  She comes across despite her obvious attractiveness as a genuine person with many levels on the screen. This role was no exception.

Having not read the book, I have nothing but, the movie to comment on. I enjoyed it.  The characters were interesting and complex. Liz, Julia's character, essentially did what many women do, absorb their boyfriend's/husband's interests and make them their own. Often time, laying their own interests aside.

This character combines her interests in travel with her search for herself.  Ironically one of her choices India combines a former boyfriend's interest in a particular guru. This I found a bit odd. Maybe his interest awakened one in her.

The ending which I will not reveal here, was to me a bit ironic and counter-intuitive.  Especially with the character's gut punch reaction.  I said, when I saw it....here we go again...

Good luck.

This was an entertaining movie and reminded me of many of the people in my life that have offered advice; solicited and unsolicited. When you look back you think, hmm, they made sense or what a bunch of crap.  Sometimes the two are not immediately obvious.
This movie was not at all what we expected. Based on the cast we expected more than just a story with some actors that moved way too slow with little purpose. Wasted our money on this one.
I haven't read the book, but i'm sure that it's very good... But the movie is very awful!! It's very boring too, I was dozing off in the first 20 minutes of the movie.

I bought this as a raffle gift for a small party I had with the girls. We enjoyed watching it and someone went home with the prize. My friends were excited, and everyone loves to win something! Obviously, this is not my kind of movie to keep and watch over and over. If it's your kind of movie, then it's a keeper. The acting and overall movie is well done, and the locations are stunning. If you are a fan of the book, which I'm reading currently - some of the stories/scenes differ in dramatic ways. That's Hollywood for ya.

I bought this movie for my mom & we watched it over the holidays! This is a really inspiring, feel good movie, that is fun to curl up with your favorite blanket & your drink/food of choice! I will be purchasing a copy for me! ;o)

The movie was ok.  Julia played the part well.  But I like lighter movies better.  It's a little bit on the depressing mood.  I bought this movie as a gift, but after seeing the movie I know my kids won't like it as much as her other movies.

Unfortunately, I think this movie watered down some of the themes of the book, and the character of Elizabeth Gilbert, to the point where it lost its depth. Part of what makes Elizabeth Gilbert likable in the book (and in my opinion she is likable, although I know some people don't feel that way) is that she is a keen observer and social commentator, in addition to being funny. Her sharpness, particularly her ironic insights, and her humor were entirely lost in this movie, leaving the character kind of insipid.

Themes were watered down too. In the book, Elizabeth Gilbert's uncertainty about wanting kids, and the resentment she feels at social and familial pressure to do so, is more of a driver in the dissolution of her marriage than it is here. Perhaps the writers/producers felt that a mainstream audience couldn't handle questioning of social convention on that scale. As another example, in the book when Elizabeth collects money from her Western friends to help her Balinese friend Wayan purchase a house, the resulting problems spur an interesting analysis of cultural differences, and the problems inherent in trying to help someone from another social world. In the movie it's watered down to a feel-good success story (as is Elizabeth's romance there, while in the book it is considerably more complicated.) The India spiritual scenes are pretty watered down too - her insights are more self-helpy than spiritual.

All that being said, I enjoyed watching Julia Roberts most of the time, and most of the supporting cast was very strong, especially Richard Jenkins and Javier Bardem. The shots of Italy, India and Bali were all lovely. So set your expectations accordingly, especially if you've read the book, and you can enjoy what there is to enjoy in this movie. If you want the true insights of the book though, just read it.
excellent

Three stars for the scenic locations and the actors who did the best they could with what they were given.  This is watchable if you can suspend disbelief and fall in love with a selfish protagonist who doesn't deserve anybody's love.  That was one of the main problem's with this.  This is a woman who jumped into relationships she shouldn't have been in at the expense of others.  The issues she had in these relationships were never quite valid or clear.  I think it's probably a testament to many relationships these days where people just leave over tiny shreds.

I didn't read the book so I imagine it was probably fantastic, but it's my understanding that some of what really happened to this author were adjusted in the movie.  If you can believe that the author's life was even more selfish than the way the movie portrays.  They actually had to tone it down a little or she would've really been vilified.

For example: In the movie the Julia Roberts character wakes up one day from her marriage to the Billy Crudup character and decides she wants a divorce.  He presses her for a good reason which she's unable to divulge eloquently.  She then proceeds to fall into a passionate romance with a younger guy played by James Franco.  She goes through the same turmoil with him and leaves him setting off on a year journey to Italy, India and Bali to find herself.

How it allegedly really went down was the real author cheated on her husband with this younger guy and left her husband for him.  That younger guy then cheated on her and left her in the end.  Now that should've been in the movie to teach one a lesson about how you treat others will come back to bite you.  I guess the filmmakers thought that the audiences would think she deserved it.  There is no way around her life.  It was all me-me-me and I-I-I.

She spends a good portion in Italy eating her way through it and hanging with new friends.  Her friend complains that she needs to stop eating because she's gaining a few pounds.  The Julia Roberts character says, "Has a guy ever thrown you out or said something?" The friend says, "No."  Julia says, "Because he hit the jackpot he's with a naked woman."  Um - obviously she doesn't know much about what the man is REALLY thinking.

All in all the story could've been worked a bit more to make her more of a likable protagonist.  The reason she's likable at all is because we're watching Julia Roberts who brings good things to the screen.  The message is hidden in there deep if you can get past all that.  And the scenery, acting and the way the film is shot keeps you afloat and interested.  There is a message in it that were all looking for enlightenment or answers or to be happy, but just don't use others or jump into relationships you're not ready for, because you then you just look like a dishonest loser.

Julia Roberts makes this work - an unknown actress might not have been able to bring as much light as possible to such a negative character.  Does the protagonist find everything she's looking for?  The last half hour of the movie is the more intriguing, so it does end with a bang, but will you be able to hold out until you get there?  If there is any great line it's the man-friend she meets while praying in India.  He says, "To get to the castle - you got to swim through the moat."  He's full of soliloquy's to which she asks, "Do you always talk in bumper stickers?"  That was a line from the movie, "Postcards from the Edge" with Meryl Streep by the way.  Originality isn't easy these days if someone did it before you already.

Hello,

I bought this a Christmas Gift and it arrived quickly. Thank you for that as one of my other gifts from another person did not! I have not heard any complaints from the person it was given to. The movie was delivered with no scratches or markings on the box. I will let you know if anyting else happens noteworthy. Thank you for the speedy delivery!
Cate Blanchatt I believe could have been a better fit for the movie. Oh and then there's the screenplay adaptation....lol.

I love Julia Roberts, and so does my girlfriend and I remembered she wanted to see this movie when it was in the movies but we never got there so I got it for her for Christmas along with a Blu-ray player for our bedroom.
BIG MISTAKE!....This movie is NOT one of Julia's best, it's her worst ever, it never gets off the ground, it's as flat as a pancake, if you are a Julia Roberts fan and MUST HAVE THIS MOVIE, then rent it and save your money, trust me, IT BLOWS, we turned it off with an hour to go, it was pure, unadulterated agony when we found out there was an hour left, the groan could be heard all over the house.
It was so bad, I actually apologized to her for buying it for her for Christmas.

Who knew?

THIS ITEM WAS PURCHASED SEVERAL DAYS BEFORE CHRISTMAS FOR A GIFT.  IT WAS NEVER RECEIVED AND I TRIED TO CORRESPOND WITH AMAZON TO LET THEM KNOW THE PROBLEM.  SO I WAS OUT THE PRICE OF THE MOVIE PLUS GOING LOCALLY TO PURCHASE ONE.
The movie captured and recreated the best of the book.  Sometimes it felt like it was "skimming over," but if it hadn't, the movie would have been six hours!

Had I read the book.  Found it to be pretentious, way too long, thin on a real plot, and boring.  Should have been edited down to the Thanksgiving scene in Italy, the wedding scene in India (and the elephant scene), and everything in Bali.

Too wordy and chick flicky.  I love Ms. Roberts, but this was just not an interesting enough film to spend nearly 3 hours on.

I watch a lot of movies and I like Julia Roberts.  But this movie was way too long and just too slow.  They could have cut it a lot to make the story move along better.  It almost felt painful to finish, but I had to get to the end.  Not the worst movie I've seen, but very far from good.  Would not recommend.

I am sad to see such negative "catty" reviews posted. It seems that most reviewers just don't "get it" and thus were not truly open to the message of the film. Yes, Liz is successful, beautiful, seems to have everything, made her choices...as we all have and do. I do not know what to say to convey the frustration I feel with a society who largely fails to see humanity and truth over the superficial and greed.
