You know how they say that "It's not about the destination, it's about the journey"?  In this case, the trip could not be over soon enough.

once again, as in all her films, you can't get past the fact that it's Julia Roberts playing Julia Roberts and not the character.  The book was so darn good and the movie itself is a great filming experience and all the other actors did a fine job.  If only the audience could forget and not see all of Julia's expressions and mannerisms, the huge mouth and laugh, it would be rated excellent by me.  The Julia cackle has come into every single part she has ever played and when that happens, the viewer is brought out of the film and back to Julia.  We know she has a huge laugh and bigger than normal smile but other actors have an English accent or whatever and they change that for a film and make their characters be the characters.  Julia can't do that or maybe she can and just doesn't.  Every person she plays can't have a cackle in their character, can they???  Other than that, the film is just fine..the story, of course, knowing the book, is enjoyable.

This movie either resonates with every fiber of your being OR it doesn't. For me, it did. It was like me in that movie, only she was more courageous. She did take the risk and listened to that inner voice.me, I am still trying :o).... I loved the message of this movie and how some people don't fit the traditional mold and have to go into great depths to find themselves. Julia Roberts gave a genuine and heart-felt performance. I LOVED it!

I agree with one of the reviewers who wrote that some more easily relate to this film than others.  The film puts into words and images one take on midlife.  I wonder if it mirrors/symbolizes Margaret Mahler's stages of development.  Italy for symbiosis as highlighted with the merging with spaghetti scene.  India with separation from other/outer focus to an inward one via learning to meditate and Bali with independence and a return to the world with her stepping back into romantic relationships at a more mutual level.

The Grimm's tale Duration Of Life also comes to mind:  The first thirty years is filled with a zest for life (Italy), the next thirty with grief and inner work (India or in the Grimm's tale:  the donkey and dog years) and the last phase (Bali or "the monkey years") with play and a generative contribution to society (a house was built for a healer).

If this movie can be viewed as a metaphorical story for the midlife passage, Robert Bly's words come to mind when he said that fairy tales give us empathy and support to look inward to search for our core beliefs.

On another level, this movie reminded me of Holland's Opus which was said to be a comfort movie for those who didn't realize their dreams - this movie for those who didn't experiecne the level of self fulfillment they would have liked or felt designed to experience.

The scenes with Richard, who "speaks in bumper stickers," seem to serve as an image of a Boomer mentoring an Xer.  A colourful, fun and decent movie.

The only Julia Roberts movie I disliked.  And I hated it.  And god I thought it would never end.  I hear the book's better.  I wouldn't dream of reading it.  My sister (a Christian to the homophobic hilt) thought it was wonderful.  All the bad reviews of this flick I read are right on.  It is tedious, episodic, a travelogue with food and religion.  She rips herself away from her husband to go (on the advice of a fortune teller) on a search for herself.  Also she looks very old in this movie.  Which would be okay if she were playing a character her age.  I planned to buy this flick (I'm crazy about Julia Roberts), but changed my mind.

In 2006, a woman named Elizabeth Gilbert wrote a book called Eat Pray Love: A Woman's Search For Everything Across Italy, India, and Indonesia. This little book depicted her search for balance, and a better life. It was endorsed by the almighty Oprah, and therefore, millions of readers across the country, and across the world have been enlightened by her everywoman approach to spirituality, religion, and what needs to be done to live your best life.

And, four years later, the film version is released. Naturally, Julia Roberts was selected to play the lead role. And, let me start out by saying, I was a huge fan of the book, and Julia Roberts was NOT who I had in mind to play Gilbert. I saw someone like Kate Winslet, or Anne Hathaway in the lead role. I thought that with Roberts playing the lead role, the story would be transferred from a deep, spiritual journey, to just another Julia Roberts movie.

I was pleased to discover that I was wrong in these thoughts. Julia Roberts is a fabulous actress, and like any fabulous actress, she makes you believe that this part couldn't have been played by anybody else. She embodies the role, it's obvious that she spent months, perhaps even a year, getting into character. She is so reminiscent of the Elizabeth Gilbert character. After watching this film, it's clear that she was the obvious choice for the role.

In the film, Liz Gilbert (Roberts) is a seemingly happy married woman. She has everything a modern American woman is supposed to want: husband, beautiful home, great friends, terrific job, etc. She discovers that that's not all it takes to make one happy. She divorces her husband (Billy Crudup), and starts to date an actor (James Franco) from a play that she wrote. She finds a beautiful human connection with him, but realizes that even he's not what she really needs.

She breaks it off with him, quits her job, and decides to take a journey around the world, that would last one full year. This journey would start in Italy, where she would get in touch with her abandoned love for food, then moving to India, where she would find religion, and then to the Indonesian island of Bali, where she would try to find love again.

A colorful array of supporting actors make this film what it is. Viola Davis plays Gilbert's BFF Delia, who is tragically underused, but she is a kind of voice of reason for the wishy-washy emotions of our heroine. Javier Bardem was the obvious choice to play her Indonesian lover Felipe, who has undeniable chemistry with Roberts. Richard Jenkins plays a man who Gilbert meets in India, who acts as sort of a confidante to our main character.

The heart of this film, however, lies in the breathtaking cinematography, and beautiful soundtrack. Director Ryan Murphy, of Glee, and Nip/Tuck fame, treats this better than he did his previous adaptation Running With Scissors. It's directed with love, and it follows the book as well as can be expected. He fits alot of gorgeous architecture, and beauty into the massive scope. Each frame is a postcard, and makes the viewer long to take a journey like this at some point in their life. It also is very resonant on an emotional level. It makes you believe that even the most cynical person can find happiness if they allow themselves to.

In the end, this isn't a romantic comedy. This isn't a chick flick, it isn't even a `Julia Roberts movie', it's a loving adaptation of an admired memoir. It will surely satisfy fans of the book, as well as fans of Julia Roberts. But, you don't need to be a Roberts fan to appreciate what this film has to offer. Its message is universal, beautiful, and breathtaking. See it.

I thought this was a good movie. I thought it had a good message, but my friend was so moved by the story. She seriously was boo-hooing in the theater! Then she sat in her car afterwards and cried more. lol So I think it's all in who needs to see a movie like this. I am always soul searching. I know how to be in touch with my feelings and nature/god. So it was uplifting, but it didn't really move me to tears. :) I'd reccommend it though.

AWESOME movie!!!  Great scenery, people, story except I would have changed the ending if I had wrote the story.  But it is suppose to be according to Liz's life so I guess it was adapted well.  Not the ending I was expecting.

There are two types of people who watch this movie: those who get it, and those who don't.  Those who don't may learn to appreciate it but it will never become a part of their souls.  If movies ever define what a person is going through in life, then this is one of those movies.

Based on the memoir by Elizabeth Gilbert, it follows Gilbert (played wonderfully by Julia Roberts) in her attempt to find herself after her divorce and a failed romance.  She decides to do this by spending the year in Italy ("eat"), India ("pray"), and Bali ("love").  In each of these regions of the world she rediscovers a part of her that she had lost over the years: in Italy she discovers not just an appetite for food but for life in general; in India she finds her spiritual center while in Bali she learns that she can love again.

This is a simplistic description of the movie, but to go into more detail would simply take too much space.  Chances are if you are female over the age of 40 you may understand where Liz is coming from and learn something from her experience.  Most men might not get it -- a neighbor of mine who saw was utterly clueless about the subtext; I myself did see some of my own journey through life in what Liz went through and ended up seeing the movie three times in the theater (my wife saw it six times).  If you are hardcore in your religious beliefs you may have a problem with her seeking spirituality in a non-Christian/Western setting (in fact, the Vatican itself condemned the movie saying Liz should have stopped eating while in Rome and visited one of the many churches in the Eternal City for spiritual guidance rather than go to India).  But that's the whole point of the movie: Liz needed to find what worked for her, and each part of the film represents a step in that discovery.  Could she have gone into the churches?  Perhaps, but at that point she wasn't ready to find that part of her soul and she didn't need the church to tell her what she HAD to do which, frankly, she got tired of doing throughout much of her life.

Julia Roberts' performance is excellent, and I will be sorely disappointed if she does not earn an Oscar nomination next year for it.  It easily surpasses her work in "Erin Brockavich".  The cinematography is excellent, the musical score is uplifting (and it's a shame that only one song from the original score is on the soundtrack album), and the supporting cast is so well that several should be up for their own Oscar noms.  If you're especially interesed in cinematography and acting, pay attention to the scene between Liz and Richard from Texas that takes place on the roof of their ashram in India -- that's all one take without edits.

This isn't a movie to watch.  This is a movie to experience.  This is a movie that wants you to feel something.  I know my wife and I did.  And I've been told watching the film before reading the book makes the book much easier to read.

Title: Eat, Pray, Love Director: Ryan Murphy Writer: Ryan Murphy, Jennifer Salt (Based on the Memoir by Elizabeth Gilbert) Cast: Julia Roberts, Javier Bardem, James Franco, Viola Davis, Richard Jenkins, Billy Crudup, Tuva Novotny Year: 2010 A memoir is the exact opposite of a screenplay. A memoir is full of inner monologue, emotion, endless stories that take place over a great amount of time and it's all told in a first person narrative. A screenplay has to be short, concise, pure dialogue and contain very little obvious emotion (thats for the actors to interpret). So when a memoir is chosen to be adapted into a feature film it's quite the challenge. You have to stay true to the events and the person telling them but you also have to work within the constraints that a feature film demands. This is what writer/director Ryan Murphy (Running With Scissors, TV's Glee: The Complete First Season) was faced with on his film "Eat, Pray, Love." Elizabeth Gilbert's classic memoir of self discovery, spirituality and love by traveling to Italy, India and Bali is a wonderful book full of wit, wisdom and meaning that can be appreciated by anyone; though only about 2/3s of that is translated to film. In any adaptation, whether it be novel, comic or memoir, there is one thing that I personally want to see faithfully portrayed: the themes (think Marry Harron's adaptation of Bret Easton Ellis' American Psycho (Uncut Killer Collector's Edition)). Of course there are going to be adjustments to the narrative and characters due to the difference of artistic mediums, but thankfully Murphy pulls it off with his film. He is able to find the right balance of addition and subtraction to properly honor the source material yet also create a satisfying stand alone film. The film beings with Liz (Julia Roberts, Erin Brockovich) struggling with her unfulfilled life and loveless marriage to Stephen (Billy Crudup, Watchmen (Theatrical Cut) (Widescreen Single-Disc Edition)). Divorce proceeds and so does a rocky rebound relationship with David (James Franco, Milk). Living an aimless life without passion and against the better judgment of her best friend Delia (Viola Davis, Doubt), Liz embarks on a round the world journey to reconnect with pleasure (eat), her spirituality (pray) and self esteem (love). Along the way she meets many 'the wise stranger' (Richard Jenkins, The Visitor; Javier Bardem, No Country for Old Men) and visits some of the most beautiful places on earth. Sure, this may sound like a seriously sappy and contrived film, but in all honesty, it's not. Murphy never lets the film dip into melodrama and handles his story with a smooth, confident hand. While he could have taken some of the more edgier parts of the book (ex: Liz's severe depression) to the screen, the movie ends up being cleaner and crisper and all the more fun without it. The picture is meant to inspire the audience to have fun, to connect and to live life, if the darker issues were included the message could have missed the mark. Murphy accomplishes this sense of euphoria visually and ascetically with the help of master cinematographer Robert Richardson (Inglourious Basterds (Single-Disc Edition)). The shots of Italy, India, Bali, and heck, even New York, are so georgous that if you can't afford to take a vacation this year, a ticket to Eat, Pray, Love will do the trick. What ties the film together is, of course, the luminous Roberts. She is, of course, a bon a fide movie star and this material is something that she can easily use to showcase her talents. She is backed by a terrific and believable supporting cast of Hollywood stars and native Italians, Indians and Balinese actors- all equally great. "Eat, Pray, Love" may not be a groundbreaking motion picture, but it's certainly a film that is enjoyable. It engages you emotionally and to me, that is the first and most important thing I look for in any film. It might not be the most faithful adaptation fans of the book were hoping for (and how could it have been?), but on it's own it's a picture with an easy charm and it's a harmless way to spend two and a half hours. Rating: B

I love a film or book about an active, engaged woman, but Liz is no Scarlett.  She overcomes nothing but the constant attention of attractive men.  In the end, instead of finding herself, she finds Javier Bardem; after a year of eating pasta and drinking wine all day.  How does that work?  Now there would be a good book!

Okay, maybe it won't win any Academy Awards, but the movie was thought provoking and in some ways life enhancing!  I enjoyed what I got from the movie- maybe more than the movie itself. I think women in the middle of life would love the profound revelations in this film!

I came out of this movie and completely broke down. I realized for once that I was not the only one experiancing this. Afterall they made a movie about it. So I must not be alone. Secondly I had advice on how someone else overcame this. I want to purchase it and watch it over again, until I get it. The message is crucial to so many women and I would advise young women to learn from this. I cannot say enough good about this movie. It is life changing, at least it was for me and obviously for others. Saw this with my Mother, when we came out of it she said " that was about you". She was right and it helped my healing begin.

My friend Pati read this book and was bowled away by it, so when my friend Madeleine decided she wanted to see the movie I willingly agreed.  After seeing it, my impression of the movie's message is that "the meaning of life is guys."  Wow, what a concept.

The heroine started out the film with a perfectly nice guy, went through a mid-life crisis and dumped him to eat her way through Italy, meditate and scrub floors in India, and find another guy in Bali.  She just came full circle.  It seemed to me she'd have saved herself a whole lot of money--let alone scrubwoman's hands--by simply staying with the first guy.  Oh well, what do I know?

It's not that I didn't understand where she was at; God knows I've done my own world travelling trying to find happiness and meaning, and I've done my own fair share of soul searching in the process.  Heaven knows I've certainly tried finding the meaning of life in one guy or another, but the truth is, there is no meaning of life beyond what you yourself give it.  If guys are your thing, then guys it is.

The fairy princess notion, however, that guys are the "meaning" of it all places a huge burden on them, and it's one that no human being can or even should attempt.  It's doomed to failure from the outset, which is probably why so many marriages collapse.  The whole notion of "happily ever after" in which people, especially female people, are encouraged to believe is very unstable.  That happy couple in the wedding photo will probably be the grumpy pair arguing over breakfast about some trivial difference of opinion.  Our society's answer to the disappointment is to discard one relationship for another that will be "better" than the last.  In the end marriage becomes "all about me."  While this makes big bucks for the billion dollar wedding industry, I doubt it does anything for anyone else.  It certainly doesn't help the children sometimes caught up in the discord.

The most important thing that people need to remember is that romance novels rarely have sequels that feature the same lovers.  This is a telling detail.  Once the "happily ever after" arises out of the turmoil of frustrated love, the lovers cease to exist for us.  After all, did the movie go on to tell us all about the boring details of the lives of the new "happy couple?"  Nope.  Unfortunately it's the boring details that constitute most of life.  The couple may cease to be lovers, but they don't "go on" as they were before.  Either their relationship matures, or it doesn't and they're both back where they started again.

The most important things I learned in my own odyssey were about me.  I'm still learning them, too, because like most people, I don't really think I need to change.  I just know you can't run away from yourself.  You're always there, where ever it is you go, and you need to learn to live with the person you are no matter where you are!  As the heroine says midway through the movie, "Ruins are life's way of teaching us something."  Yup, it's "live with it!"

By the end of the film I felt like the producers had foisted off another romance movie on me.  I felt that they said, "Yup. It's all true; all you need to do is find the "right guy," and you'll live happily ever after. And that's the meaning of life."  How sneaky.

It was a very self-absorbed story and film.  I only stayed until the end, because I wanted to see if this totally selfish, inward person every 'got it'!  I was one of the few who stayed.  People started walking out after about the first half hour and by the time she got to the 'love' portion of the film - the theatre was basically empty.  It was painful to stay until the end.  Was it worth it?  NO.

A person who cannot define themselves without the validation of others, and who moaned and groaned for two and one-half hours?  Unbelievable that someone felt the need to spend millions of dollars to put this into film.  I can only imagine how intermidable it was to try to get through the book.  Again, amazing that this complaining story made it in print!  The only saving grace in the film?  The wonderful scenery and food.  Not enough to redeem this movie; nor good enough for an actress like Julia Roberts.

I read that she is now 'done with Christianity'...well, I guess someone had a revelation!  Although, I might have kept that to myself until the film aired; I suspect that bold statement affected ticket sales, certainly in the US, before the film was released.  I love Julia Roberts, but this was not one of her better moments.  Hopefully, her next film will showcase the wonderful, warm actress that I and others love to see on the big screen!

The circumstances of the story are interesting and beautifully portrayed, but more important was the message that was communicated, a timeless one. There is something within every human being. Name it what you want (God, Peace, Enlightenment etc.)When it is felt, words fall short. What will lead a person to want to discover this feeling is an intense longing. How this happens for each person is unique and a surprise. Travelling across the world is only one of a wide variety of circumstances. The actors in the story did a good job because I believe that they were able to go little deeper to access their own experiences and feelings about what really matters, and then "infuse" the script to make it come alive.

I enjoyed this movie, but felt the screenplay was much too long...Julia Roberts exhibits her talented magic, as Liz Gilbert, a journalist who is spiritually and emotionally bereft. Roberts does a great job with capturing a confused, control freak, who is uncertain, generous in spirit, affable and vulnerable. Emerging from an ill matched marriage, to dating a more spiritually enlightened boy toy....Liz recognizes there is more to life and something very wrong with the men she chooses. So...with the amicable encouragement of her friends, she sets out to do something different! Viola Davis is very likeable as her BFF, a juggler supreme (super busy) life chaotically wonderful, supportive and self confident friendship. Liz makes an unexpected proposal to take a sabbatical from her normal life and journals her adventures along the way.

The script was good, the cinematography great, and the director captured the essence of the woman and her companions. But the film was contradictory and just about 30 minutes too long. To say Liz was in an unhappy marriage bothered me...Liz was in an unhappy life (her own) and engages on an outer journey to places of inner discovery. She sets sail for Bali to find her journey's map, then on to Italy where she easily makes friends and revels in the wonders of a culture who is like a relaxed pair of jeans...you know, with the expandable waist? Liz even delivers a lecture on how unhealthy America is to women and their body image (gasp...muffin top stomachs!) She pledges to defy social mores to her newfound Swedish friend...to just "let go and live" while in the land of love and culinary delight. The problem is the camera then follows them to a boutique where they painfully, dully, try on several pairs of too tight pants, enduring the torture of having someone help them pull the zipper shut, whilst lying down for maximum flatbelly...ultimately buying another denim corset. It just doesn't compute. I guess I was hoping for more scenes of the history of Rome and more of the amazing food and drink...too much time on spaghetti (uhm, yeah, we have that here in the USA). Found myself wishing i could see the Sistine Chapel and more of the local, delights in bread, cheese, and pasta. Okay, so a letdown with the Italian sequence....the saving grace was the beautiful language and total lack of neuroses in the Italian culture,...at least within the confines of Liz's encounters.

India was my favorite part of the story, it was humorous, capturing both the ruinous filth of the city and its collective devotion to prayer and enlightenment. Liz transcends her privileged, neurotic, monkey chatter thoughts by forming an intimate, platonic bond with another American devotee (played wonderfully by Richard Jenkins), who shares his story and prompts her (sometimes with an emotional cattle prod) to keep walking the inner path. Again though...too much time on watching someone meditate...uhm, hello? Its kind of like watching someone take a nap... not really engaging...unless you are going to throw in special effects. Our Liz was just not experiencing any significant inner plateaus during meditation, so no swirly whirly colors or visions...I would humbly suggest leaving some of this segment on the cutting floor.

Back to Bali for the final installment, where Liz reconnects with her Yoda like shaman,"Ketut," who gives her tasks,throwing in niblets of common sense, with an adorable toothless grin and weird accent. To give the story credit, Liz (Julia Roberts) does her best work here....in particular, a scene on the beach where she portrays abject horror at the reality of being alone with the very vulnerable, and sensitive Javier Bardem I("Felipe")...a guarded, yet affable divorced gentleman she is growing very close to. Felipe is so diametrically different that he can easily see she is seeking a "champion," instead of the "boys" her history involves. Liz resists, of course, in her typical New Yorky stubborness of trying to find something on the exterior to "fix" her interior flaws. Many referenced the fortune cookie ending where she runs toward discomfort, risk, uncertainty and another chance at love. This time with someone who brings out the best in her...

All in all, i would suggest this movie as a video rental...the movie theatre involved me eating too much popcorn and milkduds, during the parts that i would have left out. Cutting 30 minutes would have been way cool. Roberts, Jenkins, Bardem....all wonderful, and its admirable when anyone, from any class (even the well heeled upper, elite) takes the path less traveled...

The story begins with Liz failing out of two relationships, well aware of how each got the way it was but baffled as to why. So, in order to find herself, she goes looking in places she's never been. The 'Eat' part of the story take place in Rome, where Liz discovers the wonder of 'dolce far niente' - the sweetness of doing nothing. Except that it's not nothing, it's full involvement in the little things of each moment, and in turning the biological demand for fuel into a kind of making love. The mouth-watering, full-screen shots of pasta, melon, turkey, and more show just what there is to love, including a drumstick moment that approaches the one in Tom Jones for sensuality. (In truth, this segment of the movie made me ashamed of the bland drink and stale popcorn I had inflicted on myself at the theater's concession stand.) Since I'm not in the "chick flick" demographic, the next two passages didn't do so much for me. Liz's next stop was India, where I hoped the culinary passion would play out among the complex flavors of India's cuisines. Although Liz brought a healthy appetite with her, the 'Eat', 'Pray', and 'Love' segments of the movie didn't overlap, and India marked the transition from 'Eat' to 'Pray'. As in any good spiritual journey, Liz encoutered new teachers during this phase, and not the ones she had expected. For reasons known only to Liz, the time in India came to its end, and she moved on to Bali and 'Love'. I was happy to see that 'Love' took many forms, and not just the mandatory romance. I'm more of a guy movie kind of guy, but I see my wife's movies almost as often as she sees mine. As estrogenic cinema goes, my taste tolerated this one quite well - but I'd come back to the 'Eat' portion of the movie any time. Four stars: not necessarily because of how it matched my preferences, but because how well it seemed to do what it wanted to. -- wiredweird, reviewing the release to theaters

I was shocked to see that Elizabeth Gilbert's nauseating twaddle, EAT PRAY LOVE was being made into a movie.  Even more shocked to see Julia Roberts in the lead.  But I always enjoyed her comedies, so I was hopeful she might turn the poor excuse for a memoir into a comedic film.  I was so wrong.  The movie just might be even more shallow than the highly-touted-by-Oprah (another reason to avoid the book) supposed "memoir."  Italy was sterotypically portrayed (lots of pasta and Italians who don't seem to have a care in the world) India and the ashram were also pretty unbelievable, even Richard Jenkins, a strong character actor, could not redeem that segment, and Bali, where no one's home has walls...really?  Do only ex-pats live in Bali?  Oh, and there is a very unconvincing story awkwardly woven into the movie about a single Balinese mom with a mission to help others for whom Ms. Gilbert supposedly raises a ridiculous amount of money so the woman can build a home with floors covered in little pretty blue tiles.  The only "real" moment in the film came when Felipe (Javier Badem) is saying good-bye to his 19-year old son and tearfully tells him that a week together is just not enough time.  Having raised 2 children, I could relate to his pain.  But that was the only authentic part of the movie.  As for the man she visits in Bali, her healer?  who reads her palm? Two of my friends traveled to Bali and actually sought him out.  Guess what?  He told both of them the same thing he told Elizabeth!  "You will live a long life and have 2 husbands.  The second husband will be your true love/soul mate," blah blah blah.  Julia Roberts was boring, she smiled too much, she wept with no tears, she had a wardrobe that would never have fit in that dirty duffel bag she was hauling around and her dialogue had no soul.  But then, neither did Gilbert's book. Even Neil Young's music could not help this film. If you like experiencing someone else's self-indulgent behavior and whining, this movie (and the "memoir," a word I use loosely here) is for you.  However, if you have a whit of sense about you, you will avoid it.

Adult whining to the inth degree. I was soooooooooo disappointed with Julia Roberts for taking this one into her repertoire. She's too good for drivel like this. I can honestly say this is the first time in my life that I got drowsy during a movie and even considered leaving. It was toooooo long, too shallow for something that pruportedly had adults looking for real purpose, and too full of people committing without ever committing. Richard from Texas was the only redeeming part, and he wasn't all that. I regret having spent the money and the time.

I read and loved the book, or more accurately, I bought the audio book and Elizabeth Gilbert read her book to me. From my vantage point on the other side of midlife, I can say that Elizabeth has the same problem a lot of people have, they are in an unhappy relationship and think the problem is the other person. Of course, it never is entirely the other person but usually one doesn't discover this until after the second bad marriage.

Elizabeth chucked everything and went on a journey to herself. If you pay attention to the subtleties of the movie, she begins her enlightenment when it stops being about her and starts being about other people. Richard, who lived up the highway from here until his death recently was certainly a real person and was portrayed in the movie very much like in the book.

The scenes in Bali were spectacular. The miraculous healing potions of Wayan were as described in the book.

When the movie was over, I felt that it was a "little too neat" in that some of the angst and agonizing were omitted as side plots and not important to the main story but in the book they were very interesting. My companion (another woman who had not read the book) remarked that she was glad it wasn't a "love story". In my opinion it was a love story about learning to love yourself and open yourself up to life. A lesson we all need to be reminded of.

Do yourself a favor, read the book, see the movie, read her next book. Enjoy!

I'm partial to this actress, enjoying the numerous movies in which she's appeared (my favorite being Notting Hill).  Unfortunately, I had to shake my head at this film, after forcing myself not to walk out mid-way.

Perhaps I should have read the book first, and saved myself the trouble of actually seeing the film.

First off, the good points--the photography in the various locales (Bali, Italy, and India) was stunning.  The vibrancy of the photography was brilliant, and to say they were breathtaking would be an understatement.  The story had potential, so I believed, but I was vastly disappointed.  Overall, it drew away from the glamor emitted from the great photography.

Roberts played her role with the same skill she has demonstrated in her other films, reaching to envelop the character with an all-encompassing grace.  Her  male co-stars (Billy Crudup and  James Franco) provided perfect foils to her acting. It was the story line that was lacking.

Centered around her divorce, I understand that this is  a difficult medium for anyone to reach in their lifetime.  Liz Gilbert's journey from her divorce to her self-realization was just a little too much to handle, filled with (what I interpreted) as self-absorption before she reached self-realization.  My belief has always been "When times get tough, aren't you supposed to pull up your pants and tackle life head-on.  Running away never solves anything."  That is precisely what the leading lady did when she encountered trying times.

Goodness, wouldn't we all love to go through a trying time in our lives, and manage to jet off to some exotic locale (for a year!)  to get away from it all? Reality is this:  many of us can't afford the escape (financially), nor can we say the hell with everything, and leave it all behind.

I hate to pass out a bad review but, if you're looking for a film with depth,  save your money on this one.  (Please remember, this is simply my opinion)

Go to the movies and see something entertaining, a film that will make you wish you were off in that magical world portrayed on the screen, and not wallowing in intense and heart wrenching despair.

This has got to be one of the worse movies I have ever seen. Please don't let you wife or girlfriend talk you into seeing this. Take a pillow, you'll need it when you fall asleep. Very little story, very little plot. Very little anything worth watching. It will probably be nominated for ten Academy Awards.

Eat, Pray, Love was, first and foremost, boring.  Nothing happened--no adventure, no enlightenment, no interesting conversations, no revelations, no self-discovery (or discovery of anything else, for that matter).

Second, this movie was trite.  Reminiscent of the ego tripping of the 1960's, it added nothing new to any debate about anything--humanity, nature, individualism, all of these were possible topics.  The movie touched on none of them.

Third, this movie was improbable.  Liz wakes up one morning, deciding (for no ascertainable reason) to dump her husband and go on a year-long odyssey to discover something, or recover something, or whatever.  She apparently has the funds to do this, which should come as a surprise to everyone (including herself) after her divorce.  We certainly never see her worried about money or whether her mail will catch up with her, or how to pay her income taxes or credit card bills.  In Italy, she eats pasta and moans about an increasing weight we certainly never see.  In India, she stays on an ashram that seems to cater to spiritual tourists, but we never see her eating or sick.  She never even gets dirty.  In Bali, she takes on a huge commitment to transcribe ancient Balinese wisdom for a wise man, but abandons this endeavor without warning or excuse to spend three weeks (!) in bed with a handsome and very unusual Brazilian man.  (When did any of you ever meet a gorgeous Brazilian man who was willing to be a househusband?)

Fourth, this movie represented selfishness and hypocrisy at extraordinary levels.  She dumps her husband with no warning, no counseling, nothing.  She goes where she wants and tramples upon whomever she wishes to crush.  Given that she is on a mission of self-indulgence, it is shocking that she works to persuade a 17 year old Indian woman to marry the man her family has chosen for her.  Why isn't this girl entitled to the same freedom that Liz feels is her own right?  She does one thing that might be considered to be outside the solipsistic world she has created:  she writes to her friends to ask them to donate money to a Balinese healer who desperately needs a house.  But even that is staggeringly self-centered:  she bases her request to them on the premise that, if she were in New York, her friends would be throwing a very expensive birthday party for her, to which they would bring expensive bottles of wine as gifts.  What presumption!

In case you have read this far in this review, and in case, having read this far, you don't get the picture, this is a terrible movie.

Whether or not "Eat, Pray, Love" adequately represents the bestselling memoir of the same name (Eat, Pray, Love: One Woman's Search for Everything Across Italy, India and Indonesia) by author Liz Gilbert or not doesn't really matter. Is it the fault of the filmmaker or the writer when the piece attempts to hit the side-of-the-barn of greater meaning and just barely skims the surface? "Eat, Pray, Love: the Phenomenon" recounts the year long journey of writer Liz Gilbert as she recovers from a messy divorce and an unfulfilling affair/relationship with a very 21st century self-absorbed pragmatism that appeals to both aging flower children and their "look-inward" progeny. By combining worldly angst with the spiritual fascination of Eastern religions made fashionable by the Beatles in the 60s, Gilbert attempts to fill many different types of holes in the spirit of self-development simultaneously. Although she succeeds somewhat in her book, director Ryan Murphy's film stalls when it fails to define itself within a particular genre. Not that this ambiguity alone causes the film to fail--it ambles along prettily enough but unfortunately without enough thrust to make it stand out as a must-see event. Murphy/Gilbert's audience contains the wide subset of Oprah Winfrey watchers--those of the "live your dream" mantra that desire nothing more than to be able to make a lucrative career out of facilitating something they love. Gilbert surely fits the bill here: her publisher financed her journey of discovery to three foreign countries where she could eat, pray and love her way to bigger pay check. Just what Gilbert is fleeing is up for grabs. Her marriage to Billy Crudup doesn't work and neither does her affair with the young hottie actor (James Delicious Franco)--how sad is that? Neither of these man ask her to sacrifice her livelihood for them--Crudup is depicted as financially dependent on her and Franco blows her off emotionally when he realizes she is looking for him to save her. As she wanders through the streets of Rome on the first leg of her trek, the audience senses her confusion--is the melancholy of her past preventing her from enjoying the pleasurable sensations of the present and the future? The juxtaposition of the "Girls Just Wanna Have Fun" theme while in Italy--mucho plated food porn, the hum of Vespas and so many leather-clad Italians looking chic in skinny jeans--with the austere loneliness of the Augusteum in Rome to depict the change that the world and time has on one's inner identity marries the desire to splurge with a sad introspection that tries too hard--hinting at depression but not quite spelling it out. Perhaps knowing that Gilbert actually battled depression with medication may help the audience better understand and relate to the confused emotional shifts through which the main character traverses. Murphy avoids this descent within the modern mindset for pharmacopia focusing instead for more than half of the film on Gilbert's sojourn at the Indian ashram. Is he commenting on the fact that the status of being a spiritual seeker is just part of a look at the ersatz intelligentsia--those who emote often and within the boundaries of copious self-development/how-to realms where just living a good life with great companions isn't quite en vogue anymore? Is he telling us that enlightenment has become the newest and trendiest goal? In this sense, is it any wonder that the most predominant self-help guru of our time (Oprah Winfrey) has taken Gilbert under her lofty wings and is promoting not only the author's bestselling memoir but also the film and its star, Julia Roberts? Is he helping to build an "Eat, Pray, Love" franchise that advocates taking a long break from reality while attempting to peel away the layers that hide the inner self? Who knows? Gilbert's activities at the ashram are never really defined--her inner journey becomes trite and cutesy rather real and mind-boggling. Whatever conclusion she reaches doesn't really reach the viewer--the audience waits for the "love" leg of the triangle because that is how a film as attractive as this with an attractive main character should end--with love. All this would be very cool if the film defined itself in more universal terms. As a travelogue, the cinematography lovingly captures the Eternal City, the riotous humanity of Mumbai and the lush jungles of Bali with a glossy expertise that would do both National Geographic and Travel & Leisure proud. As a romantic fantasy--girl is married to wrong guy, has affair with younger actor and than finds the hunkiest Brazilian ex-pat this side of Ipanema even after gorging herself with indulgent amounts of pizza, pasta and gelato--'EPL' might work. However, the screenplay makes the mistake of dictating a New Age panacea for the ennui of modern life. Whereas the average viewer expects a visual nirvana of charming faraway places, he/she is force-fed the not-so-palatable pill of Liz's self-absorption. The result confuses; the storyline seems over-edited. The overall messages gleaned from the experiences in the three places don't really flow with any real meaning because even though we are treated to some voiceover, we are not privy to the progression (if any) of Liz's without-rhyme or reason thought as we are in her equally poorly formatted book. The bulk of the film's time is spent focusing on the routine of the ashram in Ganeshpuri, India where Liz fumbles through meditation, her early morning devotionals and some textbook feminism regarding the woman-unfriendly aspects of marriage. Why she is there and what she hopes to gain other than to meet the guru of her ex-boyfriend is never fully mapped out. She snaps with frustration at the gruff Richard from Texas (Richard Jenkins) also playing pilgrim at the hermitage and he speaks in zen to get her to the point where she can get between the sheets with Javier in an Indonesian hut. Huh? The amalgamation of the material world with that of the spiritual and the sensual covers too much ground in too little time while the formulaic ending of girl riding the waves with her new man trivializes the more somber issues introduced but never fully developed or rectified in the first two segments of the trek. As "Eat, Pray, Love" can't figure out just exactly what its point is, the actors can't figure out how to play it. Choreographed with MTV-ish segments of Julia as Liz in different parts of the world, the audience strives to participate but cannot--Liz's pain is explained, but it is too nebulous--too deep and indulgent to fully understand. All Julia Roberts can do is alternatively look sad or happy. Bottom line? Watching Julia Roberts travel to three different world venues as she ponders the big question of life's meaning doesn't quite work in this film adaptation of Liz Gilbert's bestselling book "Eat, Pray, Love." A better venue for this soul trek would have been a National Geographic series where the points of scenery and dogma could have been better exemplified in documentary format. Think Japan (4 tape set) [VHS] hosted by Jane Seymour. More clearly introduced information would have fleshed out the personal stuff giving the audience more background and less muddle. Recommended only for those who like Julia Roberts and simplified travel journals with fairytale endings. Diana Faillace Von Behren "reneofc"

"Eat Pray Love" is a botch. There are some very pretty images onscreen of beautiful people lounging and engaging in shallow, narcissistic, pseudo-spiritual preening and posing, some nice, crunchy, flowing, draping, tie-dyed, robes and scarves, and some heaping plates of pasta gorged down by people with perfect teeth. It's like looking at a spiritually pretentious, multi-culti American Express commercial for two and a half hours. The travelogue scenes are undermined, though, by inappropriate camera work. Director Ryan Murphy uses a shaky, handheld camera, spinning scenes, and extreme close-ups. His cinema-verite style is very out of place with this material.

Other than Richard Jenkins' performance, "Eat Pray Love" has not one second of integrity. It wants to be about the nature of love, the mystery of life, and the search for the transcendent. The main stars and Ryan Murphy, the writer-director, show no evidence of any depth or insight on any of these questions. I pity the fool who takes this film on as a spiritual guide or love guru.

I'm not sure if viewers were supposed to have as much contempt for the characters as I ended up having. Was I supposed to regard Elizabeth (Julia Roberts) as a passive, parasitic, narcissist, coward, and tramp who slept with anyone who was almost as good looking as she? She's coupled with three men in the movie, and flirts seriously with two more, and they are all pretty enough for a travel layout in Vanity Fair. None has any discernable personality. The only reason Elizabeth has for hooking up with these guys is that he and she are the two best looking characters onscreen at any given moment.

Even though Elizabeth embarks on a life-changing world tour, and does one charitable deed, she comes across as passive. Others in the film have lives; Elizabeth stands on the sideline, watching. She lives through others. This is especially evident when her Indian friend, Tulsi, is forced into an arranged marriage at age 17.

I've met Hindu women in their forties and fifties who could still cry real tears over that moment when they came home and found the red sari and were forced to start producing children for a strange man they didn't know and didn't much like. This film treats forced, child marriage as just another chance for stunning wardrobe changes and shots suitable for a National Geographic spread.

The multi-culti "It's a Small World" approach is morally grotesque, especially in a film that wants to be about searching for the big truths. In terms of the structure of the film itself, showing Julia Roberts, no doubt the tallest person there, hanging out at an Indian wedding just makes the character into a dilettante, someone the viewer finds hard to like.

In addition to being shallow, the script is at times incoherent. I had no idea what was going on in the first twenty minutes of the film. I didn't know - and I still don't - what Elizabeth does for a living, how she lost all her money, as the film tells us she does, or how she got the money back. She appears to give all her money to her layabout (but pretty) husband; why? Couldn't she get a better divorce lawyer?

Then she's off to Italy to eat pasta and tease a sexually frustrated language tutor and annoy traditional Italian matrons who don't understand her lifestyle choice; where'd this woman who just lost everything get the cash to do that? Viola Davis is compelling, but I have no idea who her character was or what she was doing in the film, except as a racial token, which is sad. I kept thinking how much better of a film this would have been had someone with Davis' depth been a main character.

James Franco pops up as one of Elizabeth's lovers, but his entire, tedious and uninteresting segment could have been deleted, and nothing would have been lost.

Elizabeth has a Balinese guru named Ketut. No idea whether we are supposed to take Ketut seriously or not. He is a fortune teller who repeats the same tired spiel to each new client: "You are a world traveler." Mind, he's reading the palms of world travelers. He smiles without letup, which gets creepy.

Had I not seen this film, I never would have known how bad an actor Javier Bardem can be when he has contempt for his project. As one of Elizabeth's boytoys, Bardem gives one of the single worst screen performances I've ever seen. He slums through the film with a phony, creepy smile on his face, the kind of smile that hides something. I was hoping that he might be a slasher; now that would have perked the film up.

There are a couple of utterly phony scenes, one with an Aussie lad we could never believe is Bardem's son, one where Bardem invites Roberts to an island getaway, that are overcooked to scorching point - you can practically smell the phony emoting - and that cheapen the film beyond redemption. What was going on with the director? Did he not see what Bardem was doing?

Richard Jenkins, as a soul-wrecked Texan seeking enlightenment, or at least the ability to sleep at night, is the one integral, worthy feature of the film. His character is real, and believable, so well-written I have to guess someone other than the main writer created him, and perfectly well acted.

See a really brilliant film about a beautiful woman on an international quest for spiritual transcendence: Fred Zinnemann's 1959 "The Nun's Story" starring Audrey Hepburn and Peter Finch.

What did I think? Well, "Eat Pray Love" is way too long. At two hours and 20 minutes, a film has to be more than the sum of its parts to be memorable. "Eat Pray Love" is not. We're never really convinced why Roberts as Liz Gilbert needs to indulge in a year off to travel the globe, and to go to the three specific places she visits. We know she wants to go back to Bali to meet again with an elderly spiritual adviser she meets there at the start of the film. We know she decides to go to an ashram in India to follow the teachings of a spiritual leader her vacuous post-divorce lover (James Franco; wasting his considerable skills)followed. Unfortunately, Franco was totaling uninteresting and not believeable as a man that Liz could really care for. Her character doesn't even seem to be particularly taken with the vocation of his particular ashram. We know she decides to go to Italy because, well, if given the chance, wouldn't we all go?  Thus begins the "Eat" part of her journey.

Along the way, the solo Roberts as Gilbert (from now on, I'll just say "Liz")meets many and makes friends in every venue. During the journey, the crystallized reason for my enjoyment makes itself known at several turns...all involve touching small moments of friendship shared between Liz and someone who has come to mean a lot to her. It goes without saying that I go to see tear-jerker movies (my latest was the schmaltzy and wonderful "Letters to Juliet"), but they play and prey on their audience. Far more enjoyable are the movies which are subtle enough to create a lump in your throat, have your eyes well up, but allow you to flow through the moment on to the next scene. There are several times in the film that this happened to me, and those moments (and the cinematography and the incredible soundtrack) make me happy that I plunked down my $9.50.

One of them involves Liz, who celebrates Thanksgiving with her adopted friends in Italy. As the dinner nears, it is discovered that the friend in charge of the turkey had not even defrosted it. The group enjoys the rest of the dinner, enjoys immensely the time they spend together, and then all nap through the night while the turkey cooks... waking in time to have it for breakfast. The scene where the camera pans across all the guests in "group nap" are charming, the reveal of the reason they stayed, the turkey, is one of those small chuckles and moments where you really feel the characters, because you have known people in your life who would have done exactly that with you.

In India ("Pray"), Liz participates as a spectator at an arranged marriage between a young girl and her groom. During the ceremony, she pans back to her own wedding day, a wedding to Stephen (Billy Crudup) that ended in disaster when she abruptly determined that she could no longer pretend that she was happy with him, while pretending that their life together was enough for her. It wasn't. The poignancy of Liz' memories is when she imagines that they dance to the song that SHOULD have played at their wedding reception (the song that did play gives us another totally charming flashback, perhaps Crudup's only likeable moment in the movie). Into the mix comes the first 8 bars of "Harvest Moon", the ethereal love song that instantly makes you realize that Neil Young is a genius. I'm instantly transported by Young's imagery, and the lump comes back into my throat. I try hard to match my own memories of Harvest Moon with the dancing scene between Crudup and Roberts, but my own memories are more tangible and more connected to the song than the scene on film. However, the moment stands out as a reason for me to watch the film on DVD, and also wakes me up to how extraordinary and funky the soundtrack is; with two songs by Young, two by Eddie Vedder and some delicious Brazilian jazz, it is unforgettable.

Also in India, the movie's best character, Richard from Texas (Richard Jenkins) makes an appearance, and from the casual nickname he gives Liz (based on her habit of eating everything in sight), "Groceries" , to the poignant scene in which he discloses the family tragedy that brought him on his own quest to India, Jenkins adds a friendship for Liz that feels more real than any that come first or follow later. Every scene that Jenkins is in is absorbing; you are left somewhat flat when he leaves and Liz is still in India, and you find yourself asking...why? Jenkins, a revelation in his role in the popular cable series, Six Feet Under, and a revelation as Theron's father in the bleak "North Country", has been wasting away, waiting for Hollywood to rediscover him. Looks like that wait is over.

On to Bali, where the movie gets its biggest appeal; Javier Bardem as Felipe joins the film and finally Liz's quest doesn't seem so silly anymore. There is real chemistry between Roberts and Bardem, and the romance is so delicious that the lumps are back in my throat again. Also hard to beat are Bardem's moments on the phone and in person with the young actor who plays his son. His joy and sadness are so real. Liz's crusade to help a destitute mother in Bali by gathering donations from America also threatens to unravel me. Bali is so beautiful, Liz becomes so much more believable there, that the infinite 1.5 hours it took to get to this point don't matter so much anymore.

And as the film wraps, I realize that, despite the harsh criticism from others, I appreciated Roberts' craft, her ability to capture you with facial expression, some of the supporting players, the beauty of her stops in the world, and the quirky soundtrack, far more than I ever enjoyed the book. Screenwriters Jennifer Salt and Ryan Murphy (who directed; also from "Glee", "Nip Tuck" and "Running With Scissors") may have left the audience stranded and muddled for long stretches, but they did manage to eke out a film that, in a way, was worth a look.

In "Eat Pray Love" you are going to see a lot of Julia Roberts as Liz exhibiting every possible facial expression for the doting camera that couldn't seem to get enough close-ups of her. This is a long movie which seems even longer than it is. We are going on a quest with Liz to Rome, to an ashram in India, and to Bali. I think she's looking for the meaning of her life, although I'm not quite sure because the movie seems to be sending out a lot of mixed messages.
Liz wakes up to find her marriage is a failure, and I never do quite figure out what's wrong with it. Do people mumble in movies these days, is the sound track turned down too low, or am I going deaf? Then she falls in love (maybe) with an aspiring actor, but that fizzles out so she goes searching the world for sustenance, revelation, and romance.
In Rome she meets a passel of friends, but mainly she seems to be pigging out on the delicious Italian food. I have never seen Italian food so attractively and lovingly photographed. Of the three locations, Rome is conveyed more thoroughly and evocatively than the other stops.
When she gets to the ashram in India, she finds that the lady guru is off in New York so she has to learn meditation from others. We really see only the ashram and don't see much of India. At the ashram she meets Richard, a man who really is in bad mental shape (played excellently by Richard Jenkins).
Did you ever get one of those fortune cookies at the end of a Chinese dinner which contains the blandest, most generic piece of advice you could find, advice that can fit anyone and doesn't offend anyone? That's the way I feel about this movie. Liz keeps meeting people including a medicine man in Bali who come up with handy aphorisms, truisms, palliatives, and nostrums which seem inane and goofy. She gets a lot of counsel and meets happy couples, but this chick has to keep looking, searching, discovering, looking...
Borrowing a line from the movie: unless you buy a lottery ticket, you can't win the lottery of life. Everywhere Liz seems to be having epiphanies and gaining insights. Some people in the theater walked out in India and never did get to Bali where she met Mr. Right. Don't ask me why he was the right guy. He badly needed a shave, was a sensitive guy, but so were the other two in her life. Is it a feel-good movie? Hard to say. She's a confused gal who left me in the dark, hoping the Bali section wouldn't be too draggy.

[Based upon Theatre viewing].

First rate cinematography and acting; sporadically first-rate script - some of the most very compelling, poetic lines I've ever heard in the movies, though there is an overuse of soliliquey...and anti-American Nuclear Family posturing.

Julia divorces her under-achieving, immature husband - a selfish guy who chooses to do a John Travolta imitation in lieu of dancing closely, to their originally chosen wedding song, with his bride, at the Reception.

She confers with her Psychologist friend, who says that having a child is like a tatoo - indelible, irreversible, as a life experience. Having a husband...another story.

Before she splits for Europe, she shacks with a local actor-to-be, who encourages her to also check out a Mystic in India. She eats in Italy, prays in India, and "loves" all over the place. A constant theme is that husbands are
not essential...for happiness.

The movie could have ended beautifully, and within two hours, in India, but she splits for Bali and meets another divorcee, a masculine man, who nonetheless calls his 19 year old son "darling" and kisses him on the lips - Julia sees great meaning in this.

Not to give away the full plot, let's say that the movie edition should have been, as I said above, under two hours, and the final half hour or so, could have been presented in a Special Edition DVD.

Title: Eat, Pray, Love
Director: Ryan Murphy
Writer: Ryan Murphy, Jennifer Salt
Cast: Julia Roberts, Javier Bardem, James Franco, Viola Davis, Richard Jenkins, Billy Crudup, Tuva Novotny
Year: 2010

A memoir is the exact opposite of a screenplay. A memoir is full of inner monologue, emotion, endless stories that take place over a great amount of time and it's all told in a first person narrative. A screenplay has to be short, concise, pure dialogue and contain very little obvious emotion (thats for the actors to interpret). So when a memoir is chosen to be adapted into a feature film it's quite the challenge. You have to stay true to the events and the person telling them but you also have to work within the constraints that a feature film demands. This is what writer/director Ryan Murphy (Running with Scissors, TV's "Glee") was faced with on his film Eat, Pray, Love.

Elizabeth Gilbert's classic memoir of self discovery, spirituality and love by traveling to Italy, India and Bali is a wonderful book full of wit, wisdom and meaning that can be appreciated by anyone; though only about 2/3s of that is translated to film. In any adaptation, whether it be novel, comic or memoir, there is one thing that I personally want to see faithfully portrayed: the themes (think Marry Harron's adaptation of Bret Easton Ellis' American Psycho). Of course there are going to be adjustments to the narrative and characters due to the difference of artistic mediums, but thankfully Murphy pulls it off with his film. He is able to find the right balance of addition and subtraction to properly honor the source material yet also create a satisfying stand alone film.

The film beings with Liz (Julia Roberts, Erin Brockovich) struggling with her unfulfilled life and loveless marriage to Stephen (Billy Crudup, Watchmen). Divorce proceeds and so does a rocky rebound relationship with David (James Franco, Milk). Living an aimless life without passion and against the better judgment of her best friend Delia (Viola Davis, Doubt), Liz embarks on a round the world journey to reconnect with pleasure (eat), her spirituality (pray) and self esteem (love). Along the way she meets many 'the wise stranger' (Richard Jenkins, The Visitor; Javier Bardem, No Country for Old Men) and visits some of the most beautiful places on earth.

Sure, this may sound like a seriously sappy and contrived film, but in all honesty, it's not. Murphy never lets the film dip into melodrama and handles his story with a smooth, confident hand. While he could have taken some of the more edgier parts of the book (ex: Liz's severe depression) to the screen, the movie ends up being cleaner and crisper and all the more fun without it. The picture is meant to inspire the audience to have fun, to connect and to live life, if the darker issues were included the message could have missed the mark. Murphy accomplishes this sense of euphoria visually and ascetically with the help of master cinematographer Robert Richardson (Inglourious Basterds). The shots of Italy, India, Bali, and heck, even New York, are so georgous that if you can't afford to take a vacation this year, a ticket to Eat, Pray, Love will do the trick.

What ties the film together is, of course, the luminous Roberts. She is, of course, a bon a fide movie star and this material is something that she can easily use to showcase her talents. She is backed by a terrific and believable supporting cast of Hollywood stars and native Italians, Indians and Balinese actors- all equally great.

Eat, Pray, Love may not be a groundbreaking motion picture, but it's certainly a film that is enjoyable. It engages you emotionally and to me, that is the first and most important thing I look for in any film. It might not be the most faithful adaptation fans of the book were hoping for (and how could it have been?), but on it's own it's a picture with an easy charm and it's a harmless way to spend two and a half hours.

Rating: B

I was hesitant to see the film, knowing how Hollywood can take a good book and ruin it.  I was also dismayed at the choice of Julia Roberts as Liz Gilbert.  Having read the book, I had a hard time imagining Roberts portraying the very intelligent, honest, and sincerely soul-searching Gilbert.  I can think of a number of finer actresses who would have been more convincing and perhaps contributed to a better film.

However, it seems that the fault is not all with Roberts.  I think the director must have played a major role in diminishing the book.  Still, we have to thank him for bringing it to life.  It is, by the way, visually gorgeous.

One of the major faults of the script is the way it didn't adequately show the depths of Gilbert's despair in the beginning.  It  actually portrayed her husband as a pleasant-enough guy which is contrary to the message in the book. The film almost makes it seem that she's leaving him just because he doesn't want to go to Aruba with her.  No wonder so many people who haven't read the book slam this character as empty, spoiled, whiney and selfish.  As another reviewer mentioned, it is her acute despair that propells her to make her amazing journey.

About half way through the film, I overcame my dislike of Roberts.  It was, coincidently, in the India segment, about the time Gilbert began to face her own problems and discovered a new depth in herself.  Roberts rose to the occasion and showed the new maturity beautifully.  The scene where she offers her "gift" to the newlywed Indian girl is quite moving.

Richard Jenkins is fun as the Texan she meets at the Ashram, although I did find his "confession" scene a little over-the-top.
James Franco as the actor didn't really impress me either...maybe because he mumbled most of his lines, preferring a lot of loopy facial expressions to portray his ardor.

The actors in Bali were good, especially the fellow who played the wise man.  He is almost worth the price of admission.  I agree with another reviewer that the interaction between Gilbert and Wayan, the medicine woman, was given short shrift.  But the importance of the Bali sequence was that this was where she found "love."  Bardem plays the charming Brazlian entrepreneur who overcomes her fear of love beautifully.  He's a little shaggy but that doesn't detract from his immense charm. He's perfect for the part--seems truly to be a man who is worth her attention, as opposed to the two she left behind.

I thought the Amazon review was excellent except for the conclusion that the story was more escape than spiritual.  To me, this came across as a remarkable tale of a genuine spiritual voyage.  The fact that it has a happy ending shows that she did the hard work, faced her own inner demons and came out a better, happier person, more willing to love and to be loved. Doing this intense inner work is not self-indulgent or escapist; it's very hard and I commend Gilbert and anyone who endeavors to undertake it. It is hardly escapist.  I can only guess that people who haven't done this kind of inner jouney have no inkling of what they're missing.  Too bad...I hope this film helps some of them to wake up!

Despite the flaws of the film, I give it five stars for it's theme.

Based on the bestselling "memoir" (air quotes because of the $200,000 advance her publisher gave her to essentially travel for a year and then write a book about it; I question the authenticity then of much of what she pens - characters, vignettes, anecdotes, and all) of the same name, by Elizabeth Gilbert, the movie is far more palatable, to my taste, if only because of the pretty pictures of the moving places where the book was set and the movie filmed - Rome, somewhere in India, and Bali.

If you hated the book, as I did (full disclosure: I ate up Eat in Rome, but the slog through the ashram in India was too much - I found myself Praying for it to end or get better, neither of which came to pass, so I simply gave up and said to hell with this piece o' Oprah-touted crapola), I think the movie is still worth your while for the well-shot scenery. Though the over-acting and bumper-sticker speak is often hard to stomach.

Watch it with the sound off and you just might Love it!

Like anyone who has the slightest interest in seeing this 2010 film, I was seduced by the Travel Channel images in the trailer and the sight of a radiant Julia Roberts in her first full-fledged star vehicle since 2003's Mona Lisa Smile. She appears in almost every frame of this 133-minute emotional travelogue, and the introspective story based on Elizabeth Gilbert's 2006 memoir, Eat, Pray, Love: One Woman's Search for Everything Across Italy, India and Indonesia, needs someone of Roberts' star wattage to give it a recognizable pulse. The challenge faced by director/writer Ryan Murphy (Glee) and his co-screenwriter, former actress Jennifer Salt, is how to make something dramatic out of what is essentially an inward quest toward self-fulfillment without turning the whole venture into a mire of clichs that passes for dramatic structure. They don't actually succeed, but somehow Roberts' goodwill and infectious manner, missing for most of the decade, overcome much of this obstacle in her sympathetic portrayal of Gilbert. After a brief preface in Bali where Gilbert interviews a prophetic medicine man who forecasts her love life, the plot begins in earnest with Gilbert's emotional meltdown back in New York six months later. Liz (as the character is called in the movie) divorces her flaky husband Stephen who has upended their marriage with plans to go back to school. She rebounds in a passionate affair with David, a younger actor, but recognizes how she again submerges her own identity in the relationship. In order to halt this recurring pattern and find enlightenment toward her true self, Liz decides to take a trip around the world with three destinations in mind - Italy where she eats, India where she prays, and Bali where she falls in love. Her first stop is Rome, where a young Italian tutor teaches her the art of doing nothing. With the help of her new Swedish best friend, this means accepting the ten extra pounds on her frame due to a steady diet of pasta and pizza. Liz then moves on to an Indian ashram where she receives essential spiritual guidance from a tough-talking Texan named Richard. She finally comes back to Bali to reunite with the medicine man and then accidentally meets Felipe, a recently divorced Brazilian who may or may not turn out to be her soul mate. Because Murphy and Salt appear intent on remaining faithful to the book, they attempt to cover too much for a feature-length film. Secondary characters become trivialized, and situations become rushed and pat. Take, for example, Liz's relationship with a healer named Wayan in Bali. So moved is Liz by Wayan's plight, she emails all her previous travel acquaintances to send money in order to buy Wayan and her young daughter a house. Yet, we get very little sense of any meaningful friendship between the characters. That's because the movie fails to capture the deep emptiness of Liz's soul that would drive her to make this life-altering journey. This is what the author did better in the source book, i.e., show the underbelly of Liz's despair through insightful comments and some pithy prose. As the movie stands, it's left to Roberts to flesh out the character's emotions without sounding like a whining, privileged woman of means. It's no small feat. When not providing the sometimes smug narration, Roberts is luminous but not the film's only standout. Even though his character has to provide the hoariest bromides, Richard Jenkins (The Visitor) manages to bring fiery heart and gravitas to the Texan who forces Liz to take a hard look at herself. As Felipe, Javier Bardem (Vicky Cristina Barcelona) has to play the feminist ideal of the modern man and consequently comes across almost too evolved to be honestly compelling. Less impactful turns are provided by Billy Crudup as Stephen (though his scene at Liz's divorce lawyer's office provides a much-needed edge to the story), James Franco rather morose as David, and Viola Davis (Doubt) as wisecracking best friend and editor Delia (similar to the role she played in Nights in Rodanthe). Robert Richardson provides the rich cinematography that captures the ripeness of each exotic location down to the luscious pasta dishes in Rome. In fact, aficionados of both the Food Network and the Travel Channel will likely rejoice at the visual pleasures in this film. The rest of us will have to make do with Julia in her prime.

The movie is based on the best seller (really, it was a phenomenon). And the critics seem to be enjoying taking Elizabeth Gilbert (the person) to task over how she saved herself.  That's fine. That's normal. But it's not quite fair to the movie - which is very good.

At it's core this is a story about having a broken heart and breaking someone's heart. I could relate. Who can't?

Julia Roberts gives one of the strongest performances of her career in this film. I hope she's nominated for an Academy Award (and Richard Jenkins and the cinematography are also award calibre).

I loved this movie. I loved the use of Neil Young - especially "Harvest Moon."

Yawn.
One star for the phony pretentious banality of the story.
One more star for some good nature shots in Bali. I would give more for the Bali part, out of patriotism, if it were not so artificial. Even the market scenes are staged (did you notice how all people in the market are foreigners?). The Indonesian protagonists (the old man and his wife, the single mother and her child) are cliches and unreal.
Waste of time.
Awesomely awesome movie!!!

This movie grows on you. What begins as a cheesy notion evolves to a lovely and felt ending.

Slow and long and mostly depressing.  Sure, there are lessons here, but it was basically 2 1/2 hours of watching someone be lost and neurotic.  It took me three nights to finish it.  Could only take small doses.  The acting was great.  That's the only thing that saved it.  And the music.
